SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of my speech on the migration legislation, I would like to indicate some concerns I have with the comments made by the previous speaker in this debate, the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson). Specifically, at page 7,716 of yesterday's Proof Hansard , the member for Bradfield said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Hanson phenomenon . . . has its origins . . . in the failure of the previous government to listen to a sense of growing unease with the continued advocacy, frequently with religious fervour, of multiculturalism.
On the following page of the Proof Hansard , he said:
It is a phenomenon which in many ways could be expected as a response to the stifling imposition of values and thinking by the former Prime Minister.
They are comments which I would like to address and address with some intensity.

If the honourable member is referring to the approach of the former Labor government to issues concerning the mix of cultures in our society and our immigration policy, I suggest, with respect, that he could do no better than read the launch of the former Labor government's policy on 20 January 1996 by Paul Keating, the then Prime Minister. I will not read the entire speech, just some of his comments. He said:

BREAK.PARA: . . . when you open yourself up to the world, when you are brave enough to look cultural difference in the eye, you learn a great deal. And half of what you learn is about yourself. And you are made stronger by that and more mature.

That is what I mean by immigration being essentially an exchange. For everything we have given to the people from 160 countries who have come here, we have been repaid. For a new start in life, they repaid Australia in their energy, ideas and ambitions, in their skills and in their culture. But, just as importantly, in the greater maturity, self-knowledge and the courage they have given us.

As for the so-called stifling approach of the former Prime Minister, I can say that Mr Keating spoke about this suggestion more recently when addressing the University of New South Wales. He referred to the `timid little creatures' like Bruce Ruxton, Alan Jones and Graeme Campbell, who he said seemed remarkably undeterred. He also referred to the fact that letters, newspaper columns and talkback radio shows were notably not unforthcoming in their criticism of him.

On not one occasion in this House have I heard anyone refer with specific words to an instance where the former Prime Minister attempted to stifle, limit or restrict any debate regarding Australia's immigration policy. The former Prime Minister did say something about the expression `political correctness'. He said:
. . . it has provided a useful smokescreen for some crude turnings in the national debate. And in the smoke a very ugly, resentful and xenophobic cat has been let out of the bag.

That is what we get down to in the member for Bradfield's speech, in terms of attempting to attribute the source of this current unfortunate and highly damaging racial debate—who let that cat out of the bag?

Prior to 10 September, which was the date the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) made her maiden speech, the present Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is on record on numerous occasions as having preached, with almost a religious fervour, a condemnation of this concept of `political correctness'. It is interesting and informative to look at the way the present Prime Minister has approached that topic. In an address to the Queensland division of the Liberal Party in Brisbane on 29 August 1996, just 12 days prior to the member for Oxley's maiden speech, he said:

. . . we face, turning around the cultural attitudes in some areas, getting rid of some of the obsession with political correctness in our society but at the same time not embracing an excessive intolerance of legitimate dissent and legitimate minority points of view.

I emphasise the words `excessive intolerance' and draw that phrase to the attention of this House. In other words, intolerance is okay; intolerance is fine. It is `excessive intolerance' that the Prime Minister objects to. Well, with respect to the Prime Minister, either you are tolerant or you are intolerant. You are not tolerant or excessively intolerant. That puts it well and truly into perspective. What did the Prime Minister say after the member for Oxley made her maiden speech on 10 September? He said:

People know that the views that I expressed on free speech and political correctness were expressed long before, long before Pauline Hanson made her maiden speech in Parliament. She had a right to say what she thought.

Under, for instance, section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act, would she have had the right to have said it if she had not been in this House? I would remind honourable members that section makes it unlawful for any person to do an act `that is reasonably likely in all the circumstances to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate another person or a group of people' because of their `race, colour, or national or ethnic origin'. In the context of section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, if the member for Oxley had not been in this House and had not had the protection of qualified privilege, would she have been able to lawfully say outside this House what she said in her maiden speech? She said this:
I believe we are in danger of being swamped by Asians.
They have their own culture and religion, form ghettos and do not assimilate.
Further, the member for Oxley referred to an extract from a speech of the late Arthur Calwell, then Leader of the Opposition, in which he said:
Japan, India, Burma, Ceylon and every new African nation are fiercely anti‐ white and anti one another. Do we want or need any of these people here?
The member for Oxley said:
I have no hesitation in echoing the words of Arthur Calwell.

Did she have a right to say that? Did she have a right in this House to breach those principles contained in the Racial Discrimination Act and to start off what is perhaps one of the most stupidly embarrassing and damaging phases of Australia's economic outlook and, indeed, its social morality, the full extent of which is only recently coming to light? I ask the member for Bradfield: who, in those circumstances, was responsible for letting the cat out of the bag? This is one instance where I would agree with the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans), in that this cat needs to be put down. But it can only be put down by one person, the Prime Minister, unequivocally and unreservedly coming out and condemning those statements which have been made.

Our system of government is challenged in reality whenever minorities are excluded from effective participation in our society by government decisions, even when those decisions reflect the will of the majority. In other words, our system of government is predicated on all Australians having a fair go. It goes without saying that they cannot have a fair go if they cannot communicate. That is precisely what the inability to speak English is in this country. It is an inability to communicate. It is an inability to be a productive member of our economy and our society. It is the inability to have your voice heard by government. It is the inability to raise a family in a confident and secure fashion so that they become productive and contented members of our society. In short, it is isolation from mainstream Australia. For our nation, the inability to communicate means institutionalised disadvantage, it means inevitable division, it means inevitable frustration and it means inevitable pressures arising from discontent and resentment. For our nation's economy it means having a sector which is unproductive and underutilised. It is in the context of those remarks that I address and speak against this bill, which restricts the ability of new settlers to obtain English skills.

One of the purposes of the bill is to roll the health services charge and the English education charge into one visa application fee. The health charge itself has increased from $840 to about $2,500, and the English education fee has also increased to $5,500, making a combined figure of about $8,000. The bill also amends the Immigration (Education) Act 1971 to sever the connection between it and the Immigration (Education) Charge Act and limits the liability of the Commonwealth to provide English language tuition in all cases to 510 hours, irrespective of the competence obtained by the student immigrant.

This bill, in so doing, will only accentuate anti‐migrant sentiments that are unquestionably being cunningly and opportunistically manipulated for short‐term political gain. The government's focus should be on empowering new arrivals to fend for themselves. That empowerment fundamentally involves learning English. In the case of many of those migrants, given the drive and quite literally the pioneering spirit that they reflect, once they are taught English it is simply a matter of getting out of their way and letting them succeed for themselves, for their families and for Australia.

The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) himself has recognised the essentiality of English skills if new arrivals are to succeed. On 3 July this year, the minister said that research has consistently shown that good English skills are the key factor to labour market and overall settlement success for new immigrants. Yet the government has cut 120 adult migrant English classes. In my electorate of Barton the number of such classes has been reduced from 18 to just three.

As I said, the cap of 510 hours is one which is arbitrary and unrealistic. The tragedy is that we have a very significant resource base in our migrant population and it is simply a matter of tapping into that. I draw the analogy of anyone who has bought an expensive piece of equipment, whether it is a computer, a metal press or whatever. That piece of equipment is all but useless, it lies on the factory floor or in a wasted corner of an office, unless it is properly introduced and properly installed, so that it communicates and functions with the rest of the enterprise; indeed, until the operator of that machine is properly trained. Once the operator and the machine are properly installed, they usually become extremely productive units.

That is precisely my point regarding new arrivals to Australia—they are a great source of talent and enterprise. What we need to do is properly install them into our society, our economy and our political system by affording them proper English training. From my point of view, any money spent in up‐skilling those new arrivals is an investment not only in their future but in Australia's future.In 1995‐96, for instance, 38,660 new arrivals were taught English. No‐one, I would suggest, could sensibly say that was a waste of money. It was, as I have stressed, an investment in our future.

In fairness to the member for Bradfield, in his speech he dispelled suggestions that migration has caused unemployment. I note that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, in a recent fact sheet entitled `Immigration and Unemployment' has also confirmed that analysis and, again, dispelled the suggestion that migration has caused unemployment.

What the fact sheet shows, however, is that lack of English skills chronically retards the ability of new arrivals to obtain employment. It results in the fact that they find employment where they do—usually in industries which are hardest hit by recession, so they are the first ones to lose their jobs. Indeed, from my experience in a former capacity, I know that new arrivals featured more frequently in the injury and workers compensation court lists. Some ignorant people said that was because of a particular disposition. I would always say to those people: look at the trades they were in. Inevitably, they were in the heavier, dangerous, dirty, labouring occupations—again, because of their lack of English skills.

PARA.BREAK: All of these things, all of these aspects of the difficulty that a number of new arrivals have because they are unable to communicate and to contribute fully to our society and our economy, have a flow‐on effect of contribut ing to the racial debate. Those who would seek to foster that debate point to their lack of success, their isolation and the fact that, perhaps because of their inability to broadly communicate, they may in many instances communicate more frequently amongst themselves. All of these things can be broken down with a bit of effort and a bit of foresight. Crucial among those are English language skills.

BREAK.PARA: It is unfortunate that the government in this bill is increasing the English language charge and is also restricting English language training in all cases to 510 hours. There is a real risk that unless the situation is redressed, unless each and every migrant who comes here receives proper English language training, we are creating intergenerational poverty. A recent survey of Arabic speaking youth in my electorate indicated that 20 to 30 per cent of Arabic speaking youths in my area drop out of school. Their unemployment rate is 14 per cent higher than the Australian average. Almost universally, those Arabic speaking youths who were questioned said that the disadvantage they suffered from most intensely was a lack of English skills in their family and hence the confidence and security that they had both within that family and in terms of their expectations and ability for career development.It is something that we can easily work at. The government should not be taking a populist approach on this matter. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Public debate on the issue of migration has dominated the media over recent months and has experienced a bit of a resurgence of late. One theme that has been running behind this public debate over migration has been the call for zero net migration or, further still, zero migration intake. `Let us have zero migration until Australia's unemployment problems have been solved' is what is being said. The solution to unemployment in Australia is simply not that simple. Australia needs an appropriate level of migration. Economically, it is essential that Australia maintain a functional and balanced migration intake program.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a good letter to the editor in the Australian recently from Mr Don Plimer from Cook, ACT. Against the hypothetical prospect of a zero immigration policy, Mr Plimer put forward three scenarios. In one scenario, Mr Plimer floats the possibility of a large company, such as Cathay Pacific or American Express, wanting to base their regional headquarters in Sydney. `While most new employees would be Australian residents,' Mr Plimer writes, `some key senior staff need to relocate'—from the US or elsewhere. They probably would need to bring their families as well, but due to a zero immigration policy this would not be possible, despite the fact that, by locating in Australia, the company would create many jobs for Australians.

This scenario bears great similarity to what will be occurring early next year in my electorate of Herbert. Korea Zinc is due to start construction on what will be, when it is completed, a $1 billion zinc refinery plant in Townsville. This is the biggest investment South Korea has ever made in Australia. It is expected to generate about 1,500 jobs locally. When I picked up the Australian this morning, I was concerned to read on the front page an article under the headline `Asia poll confirms damage'. The article states:
More than half of senior executives in Asia say the race debate has made Australia a less attractive place for investment, according to a poll by one of the region's top business magazines.

To paraphrase the article, it continues that the survey confirmed anecdotal evidence and widespread media reporting in the region in recent months that the impact of the immigration debate has been uniformly bad for Australia's image.

The part of the article that concerned me most was the section that indicated 80 per cent of South Korean executives surveyed said they were now less likely to invest in Australia. While I believe most opinion polls should be treated with some degree of caution, it would be foolish for small business, tourism and industry operators in Townsville to ignore this report altogether.

The Korea Zinc project will be of enormous significance to Townsville and the North Queensland region. It will inject large amounts of money into the local economy. It will provide a large number of skilled jobs in the region. It has been suggested that Korea Zinc could establish a chemical education centre on site in conjunction with James Cook University or one of the TAFE colleges in Townsville. It will also provide the very real possibility of other developments starting up alongside Korea Zinc as offshoots, for example the development of a fertiliser industry, a sulphuric acid facility and diecast metals production.

As late as last week at the National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference in Melbourne, the President of Korea Zinc, Mr C.K. Choi, said that the fundamental factors that influenced the decision to locate the refinery project in Australia, particularly in Townsville, `will be basically the same as faced by other potential investors in other industries'. Other South Korean investors are watching the Korea Zinc project carefully, with an eye to assessing Australia and Townsville as sites for future projects.

In my first speech to this House I said it was imperative for the government, business and industry to start capitalising on opportunities, such as the one the Korea Zinc project offers—a $1 billion investment and 1,500 jobs. To now read that some senior Asian executives view Australia as a less attractive place in which to invest is nothing short of feeling as though we are being robbed of job creation opportunities.

At certain stages throughout the construction and operational life of the refinery, Korea Zinc will need to bring specialist technicians and company personnel out from Korea to Australia for extended periods of time. Some perhaps would even be permanent. It is unrealistic to suggest that this would not be the case. Therefore, if Australia had a zero migration policy in operation, there would be some difficulties for this project.

I guess we are facing two options: either we can tell Korea Zinc to take a hike and take their $1 billion investment elsewhere or we can pursue a properly balanced migration program and reap the benefits of Korea Zinc's investment in Townsville. If we pursue the first option, what do we tell the citizens of Townsville and Thuringowa, who are anxiously waiting for this development? Do we say, `Sorry, but we oppose new employment opportunities for Australians'? Do we say, `Let us not worry that no other country outside Australia will want to set up shop because they cannot bring foreign specialists into our country when necessary'? The reality is that we as a country are not going to say that.

We could tell them that or we could continue to work along the lines of the current migration program—a program that properly balances Australia's social, economic and environmental needs; a program that is based on non-discriminatory principles. These bills seek to properly balance Australia's social, economic and environmental needs without discrimination. More importantly, to quote from the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock), these bills seek `to provide the government with the authority to deliver a planned, orderly and balanced migration program'.

People at public meetings have said to me, `Yes, the government should introduce a zero immigration policy and it should introduce it straightaway. It will solve our unemployment problems.' But when I tell them that such a prospect in all probability would mean no Korea Zinc in Townsville, no $1 billion investment and no new local job opportunities, then they are likely to say, `But then it should be an exception.' Unfortunately, you cannot have it both ways. A zero immigration policy is not the answer to unemployment in Australia and it is certainly not the answer in Townsville.

When the coalition took control of government, it took control of a migration program that was unbalanced and out of control. In 1993-94, the total program allowed about 64,800 migrants. In 1994-95, the figure grew to 76,500, and to 83,000 in 1995-96. The family component of the migration program grew by some 27 per cent in 1995-96. The spouse category, for example, grew by 74 per cent.Projections clearly showed that, had the coalition not put the brakes on the program, migration levels for 1996-97 would almost certainly have reached 100,000. Depending on your point of view, this might be either good or bad. But the damaging aspect was that the Labor Party allowed a marked imbalance to develop in the program between the skilled and the family components of that program.

It has been generally agreed in the past that the government of the day should have the authority to determine Australia's level and composition of immigration. However, despite the opposition conceding that they could live with a migration program this year of 74,000, we now find that the opposition, led by their shadow spokesman and conspiring with other non-government senators, has disallowed regulations that will assist the government in delivering a balanced migration program.

Let me quickly run through a list of regulations that the Senate recently disallowed: regulations requiring sponsors in the preferential family category to be Australian citizens, a perfectly reasonable regulation; regulations allowing refugees to bring their immediate families into Australia under the humanitarian program; regulations that recognise English language skills in the concessional family category which has a high skills component; regulations which meet the coalition's election commitment to seek full cost recovery of English language tuition charges; and regulations that facilitate the Commonwealth to recoup benefits claimed by migrants within the first two years.

What we have here is an opposition displaying its true colours, obstructing sensible reforms for the sheer sake of obstruction. I think the opposition has taken the term `opposition' too literally. The member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) got it right in the second reading speech when he said:

I note that the honourable member for Denison has indicated that the opposition supports the level of the program the government has announced. The achievement of that program level, and the restoration of the balance between the family and skilled categories that is the key to community support for the program, requires all the measures contained in this bill. If the opposition is not prepared to support these sensible measures, it will be clear to all that they are not serious about achieving a well managed and well structured migration program.

To the opposition and the minor parties the message should be crystal clear: don't sabotage the solution. The previous government allowed the balance of migration to get out of control. Don't sabotage the solution that we bring before the House today.

We have already seen the opposition and minor parties in the Senate disallowing measures relating to new migrants' access to certain social security benefits. There was an interesting article in the Financial Review on Tuesday, 26 November by the former Labor minister Peter Walsh which ran under the headline, `Humbug and hypocrisy'. Whilst I may not agree with Mr Walsh's views on many issues, the member for Denison (Mr Kerr) cannot avoid the fact that Mr Walsh is from the Labor side of politics.

The article was predominantly about the hypocrisy of the Australian Democrats in supporting Labor's opposition to measures restricting migrants' access to social security. The main point of Mr Walsh's article was that the Democrats backed the ALP the other week on the basis that:
Democrats support the prerogative of the Government to set migration numbers but not policies which implement those levels through discriminatory means.

Mr Walsh points out in his article that the Democrats endorse a zero net immigration policy which requires a gross intake of around 30,000 migrants each year. Mr Walsh was a bit perplexed at how the Democrats could support last week's opposition to government measures on the basis that they would be achieved through discriminatory means, yet at the same time also support the reduction of the migration program to 30,000. Walsh writes:

In their ceaseless quest to pick up any spare vote that might be floating around, the Democrats purport to regard the Refugee, Humanitarian, Concessional and Preferential family categories as sacrosanct. The regulations they voted down sought to limit those numbers to 66,000. A program twice as permissive as the Democrats say should be allowed is denounced by them as too harsh.

This is why this issue should not be worthy of speculation about a double dissolution of parliament. The behaviour of the Democrats in the Senate on this issue is highly hypocritical. The Democrats' `ceaseless quest to pick up any spare vote that might be floating around', as Mr Walsh describes their behav iour, will not win them any votes. It will only show them up to be headline seeking opportunists. Hopefully, though, those headlines will read more and more along the lines of `Humbug and hypocrisy'.

Mr Walsh was a little ingenuous in his article. While describing Labor's actions as politically stupid, he gave the reader the impression that the opposition reluctantly went along with the Democrats' plans. Mr Deputy Speaker, the reverse was actually the case. The architects were in fact the member for Denison and the former Labor minister Senator Bolkus. They are the people who caused the problem of a migration program that was out of control. They are the ones who are sabotaging our solution.

I reject the claim from the honourable member for Denison that the language of the immigration minister and other government members on this particular issue is more reminiscent of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) than a responsible government. The coalition in opposition prior to the last election clearly indicated that we would take these steps. There was no smoke; there were no mirrors. If the honourable member for Denison has been so concerned about that particular measure, why hasn't he raised these questions before?

What the government is seeking to do is shift the focus of the migration program back towards the skilled migrant category and bring the preferential family category back into balance. How will this be achieved? It will be achieved by limiting sponsorship in the preferential family category to Australian citizens, by saying that people must have publicly made a commitment to Australia by becoming citizens. At a time when the size of the migration program has been reduced but demand for places is still high, the government believes people who have made a commitment to Australia should be given some priority.

It will be achieved in part by making changes to assurance of support. This will act in tandem with the decision to increase to two years the waiting time before migrants can access certain social security benefits—or at least this would have been the case had not the ALP, with the complicity of the Democrats, prevented us from doing so in the Senate last week. These were designed to send a clear message to the people who sponsor relatives and other migrants coming to Australia that they must take some responsibility for their care and support. It would have also made sure that Australian taxpayers do not bear the full brunt of the cost of support for new migrants.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the government is also taking steps in relation to sham marriages and bogus de facto relationships. The amendments the government seeks provide the power to make regulations that a prospective migrant who applies for a permanent visa on the basis of his or her de facto relationship with an Australian citizen or lawful permanent resident must satisfy a cohabitation requirement before he or she is granted a permanent visa—a very reasonable requirement. This amendment is something the coalition said during the election campaign it would be seeking if it won office. Perhaps the fact that people are prepared to lie and rort the system in order to come to Australia is a reflection on the quality of life that we as Australians all enjoy. Whether it is or is not, systemic fraud is not a practice or character trait that we should either encourage or allow.
The former government brought in their own measures to combat the problem of sham marriages and non‐genuine de facto relationships. The immigration minister recently said on Meet the Press:

What we are seeking to do is to require a de facto partner to have lived at least for a period of time, say two years is what we were suggesting in our draft proposals, so that you at least know that it is a continuing relationship before they seek to enter Australia.

The minister said later in the interview that people in a married or de facto relationship would only get temporary residency rather than permanent residency after a successful spouse entry into Australia. If the relationship breaks down in that two‐year period, then the partner would be reasonably expected to leave Australia.

Before concluding, I would like to reiterate a couple of points. The main point is that the opposition and minor parties just should not continue to block measures to bring order back to Australia's migration program. Do not sabotage our solution. Do not get in the way of our attempt to deliver a planned, orderly and balanced migration program.

The government of the day should have the right to determine the size and balance of that program. We should be able to determine that sponsors in the preferential family category be Australian citizens. We should be allowed to let refugees bring their immediate families into Australia under the humanitarian program. We should be allowed to recoup the full costs of English language tuition to wealthy migrants. And we should be allowed to extend to two years the waiting period before new migrants can access certain social security benefits.

It is not as though the coalition hid these measures from the people of Australia prior to the March election. The sooner the opposition and the minor parties realise this, the sooner we can get on with the job of introducing measures which will bring our migration program back under control.

I went into the last election with a commitment to do everything I can to enhance employment prospects in my electorate. I have since spent a lot of time mediating and facilitating meetings for Korea Zinc. I have done this because the Korea Zinc project will bring hundreds of jobs to the local Townsville and Thuringowa region and provide an enormous boost to the local economy and many small businesses.

It would be ignorant to think that other companies in places such as South Korea are not watching Australia, Townsville and the Korea Zinc project very closely. To jeopardise those business and industry investment opportunities is nothing short of irresponsible. Townsville has worked long and hard to secure the Korea Zinc project. I, for one, am not prepared to see Korea Zinc and other job creating projects put at risk by calls for zero immigration or net zero immigration. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ms HANSON

TALK.START.PARA: —Australians have a right to be proud of their heritage. Over the years, we have welcomed many new Australians from many countries. Too many people have accepted the politically correct line that we have something to be ashamed about. Writing about Slim Dusty, who is a fine Australian, one Melbourne journalist said:

SPEECH.PARA: Few countries have a past they are as rightly embarrassed about as we do.

What trendy, politically correct rubbish! People like these try to make us ashamed to be Australians, when we have everything to be proud of. This sort of thing does not build Australia; it knocks it down. There have been too many knockers in recent times. It is about time someone said something positive about Australia.

Ted Seng, who was born in Malaysia and is now Deputy Mayor of Randwick City Council in New South Wales, has come out in support of some of the things I have been saying about migration to Australia. He was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald and the Sydney suburban newspaper the Southern Courier. Councillor Seng said that, although Australia had gained economic benefits from Asian migration, he did not want Australia to be `Asianised, Americanised or Africanised'. Councillor Seng said:
I do not want to see a situation in Australia where values are dramatically changed to Asian values—that's what I'd define as Asianised.
He went on to say:
I'm saying if Asian migrants want to come to Australia and live as they do in Asia, then why do they come here in the first place? If you are prepared to come here, you must make sacrifices.

What are these things that Councillor Seng values about Australia? The same things that Australians of Anglo‐Celtic and European origin value: a fair go, fighting against corruption and community spirit. Along with these goes a commitment to Judaeo-Christian values and ethics, an honest system of justice and government, and education based on English law. Councillor Seng said that Australia should stay as it has always been: a free country with a fair go for everyone.

Australia is a uniquely tolerant society. Most Australians do not care where you come from as long as you fit in and act like an Australian. This includes learning Australia's common language, English. Governments continue to promote ethnic separatism in our country: for example, by allowing migrants to obtain driver's licences in their mother tongue.

New Zealand has also been debating what the future of migration should be. They have decided that learning English should have a high priority because it is important to have a stable, cohesive society as well as one that is economically strong. It is no good having a rich country if it is falling apart because of violence, gang warfare and ethnic separatism. We do not want little ethnic islands separated from the rest of the Australian community. We do want migrants who can integrate into Australian society, not congregate in just a few areas.

What is happening in countries similar to ours? In New Zealand migrants must learn to speak English. Migrants who go there in certain categories must put up a bond of $20,000 for every person in the family over 16. The main applicant must speak English well enough to pass a test and his family must learn enough English within a year to pass a similar test. If they do not, they lose their $20,000.

These are not mickey mouse tests. These migrants have to pass a test run by Cambridge University in England and pass it well enough to at least make themselves understood in English. These tests, called the IELTS, are an internationally recognised way to test ability in English, both spoken and written. If migrants to New Zealand fail these English tests, they lose money—a lot of money. Canada is also considering using IELTS to test their migrants in English skills.

Australia really does not give anyone encouragement to learn English. We give free English lessons without any penalty for not learning, and without any real reward for learning to speak English properly. We give migrants up to 510 hours of free English instruction without any penalty or any reward for passing or failing.

Some people have said that I am a racist. This is rubbish. I am not a racist; I am a realist. I want a fair go for all Australians, no matter where they or their parents come from. All I want is an Australia for Australians.

Australians have been too easy going for far too long. No‐one has a god‐given right to come here. It is Australia's right to let in people who it thinks will help us grow as a nation. Migrants who come here must be prepared to fit in, as have generations of Australians who came before them. I and many other Australians are not prepared to have migrants come here to our country and start changing our culture and way of life because it offends them—for example, not being able to sing Christmas carols and hymns in some of our schools.

—I do not know if the rest of my speech will fit in with what you are wanting me to say. We are talking about citizenship—
—Continue, and I will be the judge.

—Thank you. I want to see a drastic reduction in overseas aid. Charity begins at home. If Australians want to help people in need overseas, they can donate to one of many overseas aid organisations. It is not the government's job to dole out the taxpayers' dollars in charity to foreigners, many of whom do not appreciate that the people who are paying for it are the Australian taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: If I am allowed to decide who can come into my home, we Australians should be allowed to decide who can come and live in our country. Migrant crime gangs have flourished over the last 20 years, with drugs and money laundering, something we rarely used to hear about.

The New South Wales Police Commissioner, Peter Ryan, recently arrived from Britain, was only pointing out the obvious when he said that New South Wales crime is horrific with strong links to ethnic groups. The present situation is just not good enough. Criminals convicted of serious crimes should be deported if not Australian citizens and, if they are, there should be harsher penalties to deter this sort of crime.

For the last 10 years, 40 per cent of all migrants coming here have been Asians. I am not against Asians coming to Australia in reasonable numbers but if the increase in Asian immigration keeps going up at the rate it has been lately in 50 years there will be more Asians than Anglo‐Celtic European Australians here. Sir Arvi Parbo is one of the finest examples of what Australia is all about. At the end of World War II we let many European refugees come here. It is not so long ago that state education departments made students on bursaries teach in the bush, or anywhere they were sent, until they had paid off their bond. We in Australia should not discriminate on the grounds of race, and by that I mean that everyone should get a fair go.

ANSWER.PARA: Treasury has released an extended version of the ABS series on public sector financial assets and liabilities. This series sheds new critical light on the Commonwealth financial management under the Hawke-Keating Labor governments. Between 1983 and 1996, during 13 years of Labor mismanagement, Commonwealth government debt rose from $9.7 billion to $93 billion. This is a rise of 860 per cent in just 13 years. As a percentage of GDP, debt increased from 5.6 per cent of GDP to 19.1 per cent of GDP. A conclusion drawn by Treasury is:

Despite fiscal consolidation of the late 1980s, sustained deficits since 1991 have resulted in the current level of net debt as a percentage of GDP being significantly higher than at any time during the past 25 years.

Treasury have advised the government that, if the budget deficits were left unchecked, government debt would have blown to nearly $120 billion by the year 2000. This would have been an increase of 1,140 per cent in just 17 years or 600 per cent in the decade of the 1990s. As Treasury made clear, and I quote again:
High or rapidly increasing debt levels may raise questions about vulnerability to economic shocks, the sustainability of policy settings and the scope to use fiscal policy for stabilisation purposes.
This government does not want to leave the country vulnerable to economic shocks. We did not create the problem, but we are determined to fix it.

As a result of the government's debt reduction strategy, we have already seen a significant reduction in interest rates. Small business and families are the direct beneficiaries of cuts in official interest rates from 7.5 per cent to 6.5 per cent and a fall in the variable mortgage rates from 10.5 per cent to 8.75 per cent. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Could the Treasurer outline to the House the benefits to retirees of the government's decision to reduce deeming rates on their financial investments by one percentage point?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the consequences of the government's success in economic management and the lowering of interest rates as a consequence is that deeming rates in relation to pensioners have become out‐of‐kilter with market rates. For that reason, on 5 December 1996 the government announced that the rate used to assess income from the first $30,000 of a single customer's financial investment had dropped from five per cent to four per cent and the rate used to assess the balance over these amounts would drop from seven per cent to six per cent. For pensioner couples, the threshold is $50,000. For the first $50,000, the new deeming rate will be four per cent and the balance will be six per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: For older Australians who currently receive less than the full rate of pension or allowance, the change may mean an increase in pension or allowance payments from 23 January 1997. It also means that those who have financial assets will now be permitted to have higher financial assets and still receive the full pension. Single pensioners will be able to have financial assets of $52,500 rather than $45,000, and pensioner couples will be able to have financial assets up to $91,200 rather than $78,000.

These are dramatic improvements for pensioners. A reduction in the deeming rate gives them the entitlement to a pension that otherwise may have been denied to them. This is a matter of equity and justice for pensioners—equity and justice delivered by the coalition government in relation to deeming rates.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The minister will be aware that between 1983 and 1995 the Labor government committed Australia to over 450 international treaties without debate. In May this year, the minister announced reforms to the treaty making process, emphasising consultation with and accountability to the Australian people. Can the minister inform the House of progress with these initiatives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Groom for his question. This question could not have come from a more appropriate member than the member for Groom, as he is the first ever chairman of the parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Treaties.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true, as suggested in the honourable member's question, that this government made an historic change to the way treaties are made by the Australian government. On 2 May this year, I announced a package of reforms which included increased parliamentary scrutiny of treaty actions prior to Australia binding those treaty actions, adequate consultation with interested parties, a proposed treaty action and an increased level of information on treaty making being disseminated to the wider community.

Seven months after this historic new system was put in place, I can report to the House that our aims so far have been met. All treaty actions are now tabled in both houses for at least 15 sitting days prior to binding treaty action being taken by the government, unless there are exceptional circumstances of urgency, and all treaty actions are tabled with a national interest analysis.

Let me also remind the House that in June the COAG meeting agreed to the formation of a new treaties council. Finally, in June of this year, the first ever parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Treaties was formed. As I mentioned earlier, it is ably chaired by the member for Groom. Members of that committee from both sides of the House have performed with great enthusiasm, showing a great deal of interest. It just confirms my view that this has been a very important and a very valuable initiative by the Howard government.

The committee has tabled four reports to date, three in relation to treaty actions tabled under the new system and one report on the committee's inquiry into a bilateral agreement with Japan on long‐line tuna fishing. Fifty‐one treaty actions have been tabled under the new procedures, and it is now possible for Australians interested in treaty making to obtain the latest information on the Internet by checking my department's home page.

As I said, these are historic changes to the treaty making process and they have one other very great additional advantage: they give the public confidence in the treaty making process by making it transparent and subject to scrutiny. I think that is a very important component of advancing the cause of our international relations.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. I refer the minister to an announcement yesterday by TNT and Tolls regarding a joint rail venture. This announcement by TNT and Toll yesterday is living proof of the fact that the former Labor government's policies were a failure in terms of trying to promote rail in Australia and the new coalition government's policies are a success in promoting rail freight as a viable, competitive and reliable form of transport to service Australian industry.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Has the minister seen reports of research conducted by Dr Bruce Hocking into the electromagnetic radiation emitted from television towers in my electorate and the alleged increased incidence of childhood leukaemia associated with that electromagnetic radiation? Can the minister inform the House of the government's response to this research?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I appreciate and commend him for his concern, as this does affect particularly his electorate. An article by Dr Bruce Hocking appeared in the Medical Journal of Australia this week. It is an update of something that first appeared in the Sunday Age in January this year. That itself was a report of something that appeared in a United States trade journal—I think it was called Radio Frequency News —back in October 1995.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Hocking is the President of the Occupational Health Section in the Royal Australasian College of Physicians, so anything he does has to be taken very seriously. I do know Dr Hocking. I have met him and have discussed his findings personally with him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much discussion in the advisers boxes.

—I say to the honourable member that Dr Hocking's findings are limited and are inconclusive at this stage. They were discussed at an international seminar in Europe just two weeks ago, when all the evidence on studies like this was discussed. It was the consensus at that stage that it was still far too early for research to show any sort of causation.

ANSWER.PARA: There are three different types of towers: firstly, television towers, to which the honourable member refers; secondly, telecommunications towers; and, thirdly, mobile telephone towers. According to Dr Hocking, the telecommunications towers emit a pencil beam and as such they are quite different to the other two and are of no concern. This is of some reassurance to me because I have one of these major towers in my electorate.

With respect to television towers and mobile telephone towers, the two, whilst similar, are not the same. They emit quite a different frequency of radio wave. You cannot assume that anything, even if it were proven in relation to one, would apply to the other. So we are actually talking about television towers, not mobile telephone towers.

Back in October, the Minister for Communications and the Arts and I announced that we had set up an expert committee, again arising out of Dr Hocking's work. It comprises experts in health, science and communications. We do need to take this very seriously, but it is something that is going to take a number of years before we can get any sort of conclusive evidence. We have committed $4½ million for further research over the next five years. It will be looked after under the National Health and Medical Research Council.

I say to the honourable member that one of the things that makes this difficult is that we are talking about a type of childhood leukaemia called acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. This is a leukaemia that appears in clusters. We do not know why it appears in clusters more frequently than can be explained by chance. I had a cousin in Emerald in Queensland who died from one of these clusters some 10 years ago.

There is no evidence that it is the television towers that are responsible. It is very hard for parents to gauge any sort of relative risk. I say to the honourable member that the kids of the parents in his electorate are at far greater risk from not being properly immunised, they are at far greater risk of drowning in a swimming pool that does not have a proper fence and they are at far greater risk of dying in a motor vehicle accident because they are not properly restrained.

If there is an increased risk of childhood leukaemia, which is in itself a very rare occurrence, the increased risk is in itself still a very rare occurrence. I hope that this association does not turn out to be a causation. There is no evidence whatsoever that it is a causation at the moment. We are doing everything we can on the best available scientific evidence. While I do understand the concern, people should try to understand the relative risk. If they are actually worried, there is an awful lot of simple things they can do to protect their kids from the things that are a far greater risk to them.

As soon as we have any evidence on this from the research, we will let people know. But I do think it will be some time before we get it. Up until then, I can only say that an association does not imply causation. With something like acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, we have to be very careful because it does occur in clusters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to move a motion relating to International Human Rights Day.
—On the day you shut the human rights office in Queensland.
—Oh!
—The honourable member for Denison's interjection is behind him.
—I will deal with that in my speech. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) notes that 10 December is International Human Rights Day;

(2) reaffirms the strong commitment of the Australian Parliament and the Australian people to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights with its fundamental principle that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights; they are endowed with reason and conscience and should act towards one another in a spirit of common humanity, without distinction of any kind such as race, colour, sex, language, religion or birth;

(3) reiterates the bipartisan support given since 1948 by all Australian governments to international recognition and enhancement of the principle that human rights are universal and indivisible, and that everybody has the right to life, liberty, the security of person, freedom of thought, expression and religion;

(4) deplores the appalling violation of human rights which threatens life and security, recognising that slavery, ethnic cleansing, torture, racial and religious discrimination, and the arbitrary deprivation of liberty, are still widespread throughout the world; and

(5) encourages the efforts of successive Australian governments to promote the rule of law and the spirit of democracy and tolerance by active participation in international forums and encouraging bilateral and multilateral policies which develop and maintain the rights of individuals and respect for the dignity of the human person.

I would like to say a very few words in support of this motion. I imagine it is a motion that will enjoy the unanimous support of the parliament. It does express views which I believe all members of this parliament hold in common. It does make certain fundamental assumptions about the kind of people we are. It does call attention to the need for practical gestures, as well as rhetoric, on the part of governments. It does refer in a very sweeping way to the need for all governments, and in particular for the Australian government and all members of this parliament, to treat with great respect and equal dignity and to accord equal treatment to all Australians, whether they were born in this country or whether they have immigrated to Australia and irrespective of their race, their colour, their sex, their religion, their nationality or their place of birth.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might withdraw migration bill No. 3 then.

—I think it is also important—and I am encouraged to interpolate this observation and I may not have done so had it not been for the interjection of the member for Denison—that one of the aspirations contained in this motion is the desire that everybody have the right to life, liberty, the security of the person, and freedom of thought, expression and religion.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is fair to say that over the past 12 months the greatest blow that has been struck in favour of one of those aspirations—namely, the security of the person—was the decision taken by the government, the opposition and all of the other governments of Australia to have strong national gun laws. It is all very well to make noble speeches about human rights. It is all very well to say how much you believe in anti‐discrimination legislation. It is all very well to run around saying, `I believe in the liberty of the individual and I believe in an anti‐discriminatory society.' But, if you cannot provide basic physical security to your citizens, you are failing a very important test of upholding human rights.

Security of the person is one of the most important of all human rights. What has been done in this country over the past 12 months in the area of gun laws has struck a greater blow for human rights in this country than any other measure or any other speech that has been undertaken or made over the last 12 months. It has provided a measure of comfort and an assurance of physical security which, whilst not perfect and whilst not fail safe, was absent in the past. It is something that will make Australia a fine example to the rest of the world.

Many people in this country when they talk about human rights and when they talk about discrimination and tolerance are very fond of apologising for Australia. I am not one of those. I think Australia has an outstanding human rights record. I think we are an outstandingly tolerant people. I think one of our great characteristics is that we have welcomed millions of people from all around the world. By and large, they are treated with great dignity, great decency and great respect by the great majority of Australians, and I hope that always continues to be the case.

I can certainly say on behalf of this government that it is committed 100 per cent to all of the principles that are enshrined in this motion. It is a motion that brings together the common assent of all members of the Australian parliament to some fundamental human values, and I very warmly commend the terms of this motion to the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I support the motion before the House. It is the second occasion on which we have had to deliberate—not `had to', that puts it too negatively; on which we have been able to deliberate—on a matter that deals with human rights in this nation in very recent times. It is the third if you include the gun laws issue, and I do agree with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in his sentiments on that.

SPEECH.PARA: The second occasion, if you incorporate that issue, was the statement that this House passed on the issue of race relations. We passed that because the issue of human rights in this nation, though we identify strongly with a set of democratic principles and with a need for tolerance in our society, is not a matter that does not have to be argued in our community. That means that the content of those propositions will always be an issue of debate in our societies.

There will always be tests presented to us. We will come through those tests better than just about anyone else in the world but the tests will nevertheless be there. The fact that those tests are there means that governments and parliaments in particular—this is what we are doing here—need to keep their commitments fresh and, in keeping their commitments fresh, need to reflect on the fact that there are often opportunities for mischief which ought to be avoided. In so doing, ensuring a strong bipartisan support for the rights of all our citizens is the best chance for us to have the sort of united society we desperately need to continue to enjoy if we are to survive in the world in which we live.

It will be a tough issue, a tough question, for this nation of some 20 million people in the region around us to survive as the years go by in a state in which we have the sort of society that we all have come to grow up with, approve of, appreciate and fight for, as many of our generations have. Therefore, there is quite a burden on all of us in parliaments around the country to uphold those rights.

International Human Rights Day celebrates the anniversary of the adoption of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in the United Nations on 10 December 1948. Speaking on that day, the great jurist and statesman Bert Evatt—wouldn't it have been so much better to have had the `Gareth Evans Drive' and the `Bert Evatt Building', but we will set that aside for a later day—declared:

The adoption of the declaration is a step forward in a great evolutionary process, the first occasion on which the organised community of nations has made a declaration of human rights and fundamental freedoms. That document is backed by the authority of the body of opinion of the United Nations as a whole and millions of people—men, women and children—all over the world who would turn to it for help, guidance and inspiration.

In 1966 that universal declaration was joined by two more covenants—one on civil and political rights and the other on economic, social and cultural rights—to form what is often called the international bill of rights. Many conventions have followed since then, on the elimination of racial discrimination, the elimination of discrimination against women, and a convention against torture.

The decades since the end of the Second World War, and formed by the two great wars this century—the only two total wars—have seen human rights elevated into the global agenda and international relations. This has been a great victory for the idea of the rights of the individual. Human rights now vie for attention on an agenda previously preoccupied by the simple calculation and use of military power.

Australia's record in advancing the cause of human rights internationally is a very proud one. As the motion states, all Australian governments since 1948 have supported the principle of universal and indivisible human rights. Human rights issues present a substantial challenge for Australian foreign policy in the region. As our regional neighbours grapple with their human rights issues, the challenge for Australia is to develop a consistent and appropriate response both for the region and befitting Australian values and concerns.

In this context I want to point to a couple of developments in the region—a couple of statements as much as developments—which I think offer great hope for the universality of the sorts of rights that we are dealing with. Sometimes a bogus proposition is put before us that there are distinctive types of rights or attitudes, rights that are different from culture to culture, and there is no universal element to them. There is an argument amongst some of the governments in the region around us that this happens to be the case.

But there is also a contrary position expressed, and I was moved to read a recent speech by the Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, on precisely this matter. I do not know the extent to which the speech attracted publicity in his own country, but it was an extraordinarily articulate expression of the universal questions that are involved in these declarations. I will quote one or two passages from it:

If we in Asia want to speak credibly of Asian values, we too must be prepared to champion those ideals which are universal and which belong to humanity as a whole. It is altogether shameful, if ingenious, to cite Asian values as an excuse for autocratic practices and denial of basic rights and civil liberties. To say that freedom is western or unAsian is to offend our own traditions as well as our forefathers who gave their lives in the struggle against tyranny and injustices. . . it is certainly wrong to regard society as a kind of false god upon whose altar the individual must constantly be sacrificed. No Asian tradition can be cited to support the proposition that in Asia the individual must melt into the faceless community.

The rest of his speech was somewhat along those lines, so those were two golden passages from it. The affirmation that there is not a so-called Western interpretation of universal human rights from one of the most influential regional politicians is a very important and very helpful development and ought to be recognised on this day in this country and in this parliament.

There are other developments in this regard too. I have been impressed in recent times by the efforts of the human rights commission in Indonesia. It was established by the government but, in the reports that have been put forward by it subsequently, very obviously operates at arms length. From time to time, official handling of political demonstrations and other activities have attracted the unfavourable attention of and public exposure by their human rights commission. The fact that that is so well accepted—that gradually incorporated within the political structure of our nearest neighbour is an ongoing analysis of their society's performance against a set of tests which are essentially universal in application—is a very important development in the area and it ought to be acknowledged.

There is no area or sensitive concern that this human rights commission will not go into. Indeed, I understand it has just opened an office in Timor. These are two developments which I would draw attention to, including the statement by Anwar Ibrahim—there are many others as well—because we are discussing values which we believe to be universal in the statements that are made here.

There have been one or two initiatives in the area of human rights which this government has related to, and I would caution the government against the direction in which it has gone. I acknowledge the point the Prime Minister makes: obviously your right to life, your capacity to survive, is quite clearly the most fundamental of political and human rights. The ability to live in a society free from the thought that, if you go into any public place, you stand a reasonable chance of being shot is quite clearly an important development. The fact that we are able to protect the community from that is a very important thing.

There are one or two other areas, however, where I do not think the government has done itself the credit that it ought to—and it ought to use this particular day to reflect upon those. The first that I would identify is our reluctance to enter into an agreement with the EEU, not simply on the basis of a reasonable argument over whether or not agricultural protection elements of it are things that we want to sign up to, or wish to press them on further, but a declaration in those agreements. They do not actually have to sign agreements with us. From their point of view, they make it amply clear to us—whatever we might think about them; we are perfectly expendable on these agreements—that we have chosen to challenge them not simply on areas where we were debating with them the content of that particular agreement—reasonable commercial issues—but also on an area where we were not holding a debate with them, signing up to the human rights clause in their agreements, which they have put automatically to every country that they effectively do business with. I would draw attention to the sentiments expressed by Dagmar Roth‐Behrendt, a member of the European parliament, who said last week when questioned as to the Australian attitude on this human rights issue:

Really, I have to say we don't need the agreement necessarily. If they don't want to sign it they should not sign it because the first time that I ever thought about problems with human rights in Australia was now when I heard that the Australians don't like this clause in the framework agreement.

They did not care particularly much whether we chose to go down that road or not. Whatever else you do with the Europeans—and by all means twist their arms up behind their backs on the subject of their agricultural protection; it is very important that we do this—we should not compromise our stand by putting forward what seems to them such outlandish views on a set of principles which we have absolutely no trouble signing up to, I would have thought; in fact, signing up to what is precisely here in this motion.

The second area relates to the ILO. We have taken a stance in which we have argued with the Americans that on the position they are putting forward, that before they consider or whilst they are considering trade matters, they may wish to consider the rights of workers and the rights of children not to be enslaved and other general human rights and environmental matters—
Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not had any agreements with you on time, as far as I am aware.
—We did actually.
—Yes.

—I am not aware of any. The position as far as the ILO is concerned is one which you need to bear very much in mind. Our defence for not dealing with that in the context of those issues and the context of the world trade arrangements, not a completely unreasonable position at all, is that those issues—which are again very important human rights issues—ought to be dealt with in the ILO. We choose not to do that, and we cannot do that credibly simply because we have so massively downgraded our participation in the ILO that it is a matter of grave concern when considering one of these human rights issues.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an excellent motion, but it is a motion that provides us with an opportunity in this very good society of ours, in this society which is one of the most tolerant communities in the world, to always inspect our own standards in human rights and the stands that we take internationally. We should not simply let these motions go by on the nod without using them as an occasion to comment on those areas.

Also, we read in reports after the demonstrations in Rangoon in the last few days that there has been a crackdown on universities where there has been repression against students. We should admire Daw Aung San Suu Kyi not only for the way in which she stood up to the SLORC regime but also for the fact that she represents the basic essence of the freedoms to which we would hope, in the expression of democracy, the people of Burma might some day be able to realise. In other words, the administration of law by impartial members of a judiciary—not part of elected officers and not part of officers exercising power in whatever way but, having been appointed, exercising power and then dispassionately fulfilling their function at arm's length from the government for the time being. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this motion on International Human Rights Day, which reaffirms our support for the Universal Declaration of Human Rights that was adopted on this day 48 years ago. SPEECH.PARA: I was pleased to note that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) this day at the National Press Club picked up those very sentiments in his address. In the few moments available to me today I want to especially refer to the government's policies concerning the work of the International Labour Organisation—the organisation which only this week the government has made so much of as the forum to address international labour standards, including child labour exploitation. It is a state of affairs highlighted by UNICEF's 1997 report entitled State of the world's children, which I believe the minister is going to release on Thursday of this week.

Although Australia has been a leading member of the ILO for more than 70 years, the government has now drastically curtailed our involvement in that organisation. Tragically, I point out to the House today that it appears we will no longer be a member of the ILO's working party on the social dimensions of trade liberalisation—the very instrument that the minister identified as being the key to the ILO's attack on the exploitation of children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chair of the parliament's human rights subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and Chair of the Parliamentary Amnesty International Group, I am particularly pleased to support this motion today on International Human Rights Day. As you will be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, human rights are long understood but only comparatively recently defined in international law by the international bill of rights, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in 1948, plus the international covenants in 1996 on civil and political rights and on economic, social and cultural rights. Other conventions have followed, giving greater definition to internationally acceptable rights.

SPEECH.PARA: The standards defined in the various covenants are both broad and basic and therefore difficult to dispute: the preservation of the inherent dignity of human life, the right to life, liberty, freedom of thought and expression, and the pursuit of justice and peace. The importance of universality and indivisibility was reaffirmed at the Vienna World Conference on Human Rights in June 1993. All nations then agreed to the principles in the final declaration. Therefore, there is an international consensus that there is no cultural difference in what constitutes human rights.

The end of the Cold War should offer opportunities to implement human rights standards in a way that was impossible when the world was sensitive to a moral competition between two political philosophies, yet any cursory look at the state of the world would recognise a bleak prospect indeed. Fierce internal disputes of considerable savagery have broken out in most continents: Rwanda, Bosnia, Afghanistan and Sri Lanka.

More than any other issue, the international community should address the issue, it seems to me, of minority rights—the most urgent and the most vexed issue facing the United Nations and the major threat to world security. There is a need to rethink the idea of national self-determination, remove from it its secessionist tendencies and its inherent approval of national ethnic purity. It is a dangerous and divisive notion in a mobile world.

Moreover, governments cannot maintain national cohesion by force and the continual oppression of minorities. Effective and successful multiracial and multi‐ethnic states need to express their diversity in institutions and political structures which genuinely accommodate the aspirations of their minorities. Failure to make that accommodation—or worse, abuse and oppression of minorities—gives moral force to claims for independence and secession. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights says:
It is essential, if man is not to have recourse, as a last resort, to rebellion against tyranny and oppression, that human rights should be protected by the rule of law.

The pursuit of human rights is a matter of great importance for Australians. It is one of our defining characteristics, expressed colloquially as the `fair go' philosophy. There is broad cross-party support in the parliament for human rights principles. The human rights subcommittee in this parliament gets an enormous volume of correspondence from Australian citizens. There is considerable consensus of view expressed by people on their expectations on this issue.

There is, and always has been, a gulf between theory and practice. Implementation is the real test of commitment. All nations, including our own, have weaknesses that must be addressed. Just as the values underpinning human rights are universal, so the human weaknesses—cruelty, tyranny, racial intolerance and war—are universal. For us, the flaws in our record are in the treatment of Aboriginal people, the homelessness amongst youth, the treatment of the mentally ill, violence against women and violence against children, which is particularly topical at the moment.

Australia is generally well served by its legal framework, and its record overall is a laudable one. Australia genuinely tries to live up to the obligations that it has agreed to. We believe in the rule of law and the protection of the weak against the strong. Having said that, however, we should also be aware that any failure to maintain the highest standards undermines the fundamental principles upon which the nation defines itself: vigilance is ever important. I thank the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the deputy chair of the two organisations mentioned by the previous speaker, the member for Aston (Mr Nugent), I am pleased to support this motion. International Human Rights Day is an important day in the calendar because human rights are never easily achieved. They can be easily diminished, they are less easily improved, and their protection requires eternal vigilance.

BREAK.PARA: The processes of democracy and the protection of human rights are intricately linked. Democracy—through recurrent elections, an independent judiciary and a free press—minimises the possibility for dictatorship and allows individuals avenues for complaint and the redress of grievances. Human rights are best protected and preserved by scrutiny through the free press and the democratic institutions of parliament.

This parliament has always been a forum for the debate on human rights. All legislation is about the balancing and the defining of rights. The Australian Parliamentary Amnesty International Group is a relatively unusual group, rare in the parliaments of the world. It keeps human rights issues, particularly relating to prisoners of conscience, before the parliament. In the domestic sphere, there is a Senate committee, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, whose specific terms of reference are to examine all legislation to ensure that it does not offend human rights principles.

Over recent years, parliament has instituted new and important mechanisms to enhance the promotion and protection of human rights. In 1991, the human rights subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade was formed. Over the last five years, it has produced reports on human rights in a wide range of areas; it has given access to community groups from all over Australia to the parliament; it has made recommendations on domestic policy frameworks on aid, trade and human rights, on peacekeeping, on children's rights, on indigenous people's rights, on women's rights and on workers' rights; and it has discussed and debated issues of principle in this country and in the region. In the process, it has increased the knowledge of the parliament about international human rights standards, and the weaknesses in policy and processes which the government has redressed.

The human rights subcommittee debated the role of parliament in the treaty making process in its 1994 report and found the current arrangements to be unsatisfactory. It recommended greater parliamentary involvement. This matter was subsequently examined by the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee. Its recommendation for a treaties committee has been implemented in this parliament. I am pleased to say the Chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, the member for Groom (Mr Taylor), is in the chamber. This is an important change and an enhancement of the role of parliament in relation to treaty making.

The inquiries that the human rights subcommittee has conducted have affirmed the universality and indivisibility of human rights and have informed members of details of situations all over the world where torture and cruelty remain prevalent. It is distressing that so many unresolved conflicts continue which devastate people's lives and destroy the prosperity of so many nations. They continue in Burma, Sri Lanka, East Timor, Bougainville, Tibet, Rwanda, the Sudan and the former Yugoslavia.

The committee has also been reminded that, whilst Australia's record at home is good by any international standards, there are still serious unresolved problems that we must address. These include high rates of violence against women; the abuse and neglect of too many children; youth homelessness; and Aboriginal disadvantage and unemployment, leading to high rates of incarceration, deaths in custody, and poor health and housing standards.

There are shortcomings in our performances. We do not have a national law regarding racial vilification, although some states do have such legislation. Internationally, there are issues such as child labour, which was mentioned by the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton). We should be showing the lead there; we are not. I share his concerns about the downgrading of our representation and our role in the ILO.

For a country that has a good record and has support on both sides, I am appalled that the government will not sign up to the human rights article with the European Commission relating to trade. I know it is a sophisticated argument, but we are sending out the wrong message. I am concerned too about the recent debate initiated by the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). It has done little to enhance Australia's image abroad concerning human rights. Again, it sends the wrong message. On International Human Rights Day, it is valuable to recall the importance of eternal vigilance and continuous monitoring at home.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed an honour to speak today to this motion. It is so easy for those of us living in Australia, an island apart from the tragedies and major human rights abuses of the world, to dismiss the urgency of the need to correct those abuses.
