SPEECH.PARA: In the short time I have available, I want to concentrate on one issue of human rights. On this International Human Rights Day, I appeal to the Indonesian government to reappraise its policy on East Timor and for Australia to reappraise its acquiescent policy of over 20 years on this issue.

It is too late to turn back the clock. The Portuguese abandoned their former colony and cannot legitimately claim to have any lasting commitment to the country. But most so‐called world leaders have stood aside for more than two decades, hands over eyes, and wished the Indonesians would get on with the integration of East Timor as quickly and bloodlessly as possible. There is no relationship more important to Australia than Indonesia's.

Not to speak out on human rights abuses such as these, especially on occasions such as International Human Rights Day, is to betray our own conscience and, worse, to betray those battling racial, religious, social and economic persecution around the world who need us—perhaps the freest, most peaceful nation on earth—to take up their cause, while remaining as we are—open, tolerant and honest—but also needing to be less selfish and always alert to the inequalities within our own borders. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The widespread concern caused by the government's failure to guarantee that the residents of rural and regional areas will continue to have access to local telephone calls at the same price as city residents.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to make a prediction. The prediction that I make to my colleagues is that, shortly after 1 July 1997, Telstra will introduce for a very select number of subscribers who live in exclusive suburbs in Sydney and Melbourne a cheaper local phone charge. It could be 20c. They might match Optus's new local call rate in those exclusive suburbs.

SPEECH.PARA: My prediction to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to my colleagues is that the lower 20c rate in those very lucky suburbs will not be extended nationally to all of the other subscribers right across the country. It will be available only in those suburbs where Telstra is competing with Optus. It will be available only in those suburbs where Optus has rolled out the pay TV cables and where Optus has introduced local phone calls. That is the prediction I make this afternoon.

What has triggered the opposition's interest in this is the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) got a bit carried away with the action by some senators on Telstra last week. An article by Michael Gordon in the Weekend Australian reported what the Prime Minister allegedly said to his party room last week, and I would like to share it with the House. According to Michael Gordon, the Prime Minister made a `pledge to the government party‐room that those in remote areas will have all the "whiz-bangery" that the new technology has to offer'—and here is the crucial bit—`at the same price as those in the cities'. So the people in remote areas will get these new services at the same price as those people in the cities. That is what the Prime Minister said to his own party room last week, according to Michael Gordon. We put that to the Prime Minister yesterday, and he certainly did not deny it. So the Prime Minister's view is that the people in the bush should get these services at the same price as their city cousins.

What is the most basic service that people in the bush use? The answer is local calls. That is the most commonly used service and is the one that is most important to people who live in rural and regional Australia. That is the service that is at risk because Telstra has a monopoly on local telephone calls in almost every part of Australia. That is what the Prime Minister said to his party room last week.

In the House yesterday, we all know that the Prime Minister got into a bit of strife. The shoulders were twitching away. He was given a detailed briefing by the member for Bass, the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith), who is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston). Lots of detailed information was given to the Treasurer (Mr Costello). The Treasurer rushed up to whisper in the Prime Minister's ear and, after getting that detailed briefing from the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, this is the pearl of wisdom we got from the Prime Minister. In answer to our third question on whether there would be differential prices, the Prime Minister said:
Let me say in answer to the Leader of the Opposition that obviously the arrangements that apply in local areas covered by Telstra are going to continue.

So what are the arrangements that currently apply? There are three protections for people who live in the bush. Firstly, under section 183 of the Telecommunications Act, there is a ban on discriminatory pricing, except in certain circumstances that I will go to in a minute. Secondly, the minister has the power to direct the board of Telstra to carry out certain actions—for example, to look after people in the bush. Thirdly, at the moment, Telstra remains 100 per cent government owned. Ultimately, that means that the people of Australia can hold the government responsible for stupid decisions or decisions that adversely affect people in the bush. They are the three protections that people have under the current arrangements, arrangements which the Prime Minister said would continue.

Once you remove those three elements—once you abolish section 183, once you remove the power of the minister to direct Telstra and once Telstra is no longer 100 per cent government owned—the protections that people in the bush have enjoyed to date will be lost. I will explain how that would occur in this matter of public importance this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope the minister is listening.
—I am sure he is because, if anybody is going to be burnt by this proposal, it is the person who represents a town like Launceston. It is no coincidence—
—He has been burnt before.
—He has been burnt before—burnt by his own policy on cuts to the ABC.
—It was a good idea at the time.

—It was a good idea at the time, he said. Well, he has given it a second go. Isn't it a coincidence that the cutbacks Minister Alston is making are almost the same size as the ones shadow minister Smith was proposing in 1993? I am sure they will be just as successful! We are going to make sure that the residents of Launceston understand the impact these changes in telecommunications will have on them. As the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government should know—
—Headquarters are going down to Tasmania.
—The minister refers to the headquarters of his office and the cost of its refurbishment. We will not go into that this afternoon.
—The minister might restrain his enthusiasm until it is his turn to speak.

—Can I say to the member for Bass that it is no coincidence that the residents of Launceston pay 25c for a local call—the same price as the residents of Chatswood. That is no coincidence. It is because of section 183. Section 183 is what guarantees to the residents of Launceston, the residents of Muswellbrook, the residents of Pendle Hill, the residents of Prospect and the residents of every electorate right throughout the country that the basic charge for a local call is 25c.

BREAK.PARA: Revealed in the Australian today was the government's view of the future under its changes to telecommunications. After the Prime Minister's shoulders were twitching during question time yesterday as he got into trouble, he got his office to speak to the media. This is what resulted in the article in the Australian. The article said:
His office said later that local call charges would not be allowed to rise in regional Australia—or anywhere else—but the extent of price reductions could vary between areas.
The extent of price reductions would vary, as I explained.

Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, it costs 25c now for a local call in your electorate and in other electorates throughout the country. But, if Telstra dropped the price to only 20c in Chatswood to match Optus after 1 July 1997, do you think it would be fair to your constituents if they had to keep paying 25c for their local calls? That is what section 183 says. If Telstra wants to drop the price of local calls in Chatswood, it can drop the price of local calls right throughout the country, including Launceston. That is what section 183 tries to protect.
In the same article in the Australian, we have the following quote:

The Minister for Communications, Senator Alston, has confirmed Telstra will be free to charge different prices for customers in different cities or towns when the industry is opened to all‐comers on July 1.
So we have some admissions. We have the admissions that that is what this government has planned for people who live in regional Australia.

It was also quite interesting to hear the Leader of the National Party in the Senate, Senator Boswell. It is good to see we have got one member of the National Party here. I hope he is participating in the debate. It is the people who live in those National Party electorates who are going to be hardest hit by these changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Werriwa is probably correct. I suspect that the honourable member would be a supporter of the member for New England rather than a supporter of Tim, but we will let the cards fall where they will. Your leader in the Senate, Senator Boswell, was questioned about the threat to people in the bush from abolishing this ban on discriminatory pricing. He was asked this question:

BREAK.PARA: . . . how can you make that guarantee—
that people in the bush will be protected—
when it's privatised?
Senator Boswell replied:

Well, it isn't privatised at the moment and the Government owns two‐thirds of it. So, the Government is a majority shareholder. So let's just not jump the sense of the bridges that we haven't come to yet.
Translated from Queensland‐speak, I think that means—

TALK.START.PARA: —He's not much of a jumper, but he certainly did say that he believed the rural subscribers would be protected because the government would remain a majority shareholder.

BREAK.PARA: We all know that, once you sell a significant portion of a company, under Corporations Law you lose the ability to control the company, to direct the company to carry out your actions. The Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, who is at the table, can confirm once again—we have had him confirm it once in the past—that, if the government does sell a third of its shares, the government cannot do what Senator Boswell and the National Party thinks it can do; the government cannot protect rural people, even though it has two-thirds of the shares. That would, in the words of corporate lawyers, oppress the minority shareholders. So it is quite clear that the government retaining two-thirds of the shares is no protection whatsoever.

Let us focus on section 183. Having admitted in this morning's papers that Telstra will be allowed to reduce its local call charges in the affluent suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne but will not be forced to reduce prices in Launceston and all the other places, the government needed a line for question time. The line they had for question time—and no doubt the line that the minister will come up and parrot in his response this afternoon—was that section 183 might require you to have uniform prices across the country, but there are certain exceptions under section 185.

The Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government used to be the telecommunication industry ombudsman, and he claims to understand the Telecommunications Act. This will put him to the test this afternoon: will he confirm for us that the only exceptions that are allowed under section 185 are discounts for flexiplans that are available to everyone in the country? They have to be freely available or they don't hold up. This includes the sorts of discounts that pensioners enjoy—every pensioner, right throughout the country. Also included are the sorts of discounts that are available to businesses that have got a certain volume. If they reach that certain volume, wherever they are in the country, they are entitled to that same discount under section 185.

Minister, when you come to this dispatch box, you will have to admit that your defence in question time has come tumbling down. It is no coincidence that 25c is the standard rate for local calls in Launceston, Queensland and Western Australia. That is because of section 183. Section 183 and the power of the minister to direct Telstra are the only two things that stand between uniform local call charges across the country and affluent suburbs in Sydney and Melbourne getting that discount.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you may wonder why I say it is only the people who live in the affluent suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne that will get the discounts. The reason I say that is that is where Optus Vision has chosen to roll out its pay TV cable in the first place and that is where Optus Vision is offering the 20c local call charges.

We believe that section 183 should be retained because, if it is good enough to cut local call charges in Wollstonecraft, it should be good enough to cut local call charges in Wollongong. If it is good enough to cut local call charges in Hunters Hill, they should be cut in Pendle Hill as well. If they can be cut in Toorak, they should be cut in Ballarat as well. We believe that section 183 and the power to direct is what is required to make sure that that continues. Telstra has enormous market power. It has this monopoly inheritance. Section 183 makes sure that any concessions to people, wherever they may be, should flow on to all Australians, wherever they may live.

The point we want to make is that at the moment Optus Vision is saying they will roll out in only some suburbs of Sydney, some suburbs of Melbourne, some suburbs of Adelaide and, if we are lucky, some suburbs of Brisbane. If you are not lucky enough to live in one of those affluent suburbs; if you make the mistake of living in Perth, or anywhere in Tasmania; or if you make the mistake of being a telephone subscriber in any regional town, any rural town, Optus Vision will not be installing the cables in your street. Some people might think that is a good thing. It means you will not get those cheaper local calls from Optus Vision. Under this government's telecommunication regime, if Optus Vision do not have a cable running down your street, you will not get the discounts on local calls. You will not get the benefits of that price competition that they are saying is going to flow across the land. That is the point we are trying to make. If you do not have section 183 and the power to direct, there will be enormous pressure on Telstra and its board to maximise its profits by dropping the prices only in those suburbs where there is direct competition with Optus Vision.

The other defence the government had in question time was that they guarantee that through the price caps you will pay no more. They will not guarantee that you will pay the same. They will only guarantee that you will pay no more. We believe that, if it is good enough for people in the affluent suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne to get discounts on their local calls, those discounts should be available to all Australians—wherever they may live.

As the Prime Minister himself said when he launched the Optus Vision local call discounts, `The local telephone call is as Australian as a gum tree.' He said that it `gives comfort and support, particularly to older people'. That is what the Prime Minister said back in June. If it is like the Australian gum tree and it is giving support and comfort to Australians in affluent suburbs, why can't people who live outside those affluent suburbs get the same support and comfort at discount rates which people in the affluent suburbs of the Prime Minister's electorate are going to get?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) for his contribution. In terms of the current telecommunications legislation regime, which was put in place in 1991 by the present Leader of the Opposition when he was minister, it is clear from the information that I have been provided with—and I did fossick around this morning, after being challenged by the question asked yesterday—that Telstra can charge different amounts for local calls in the country as against the city if it can justify doing so on the basis of different costs, that is, Telstra can discriminate in this way if Austel decides that it is cost justified under section 185A(2) of the Telecommunications Act.

As I pointed out in question time, you must read section 185 in conjunction with section 183. I will not quote those sections at present, but section 183 fundamentally says there shall not be a price discrimination except in circumstances under the exemptions, and 185A is one of the exemptions—that is, where a carrier can show that there are cost justification reasons for doing so. Quite clearly, it costs a lot more to provide call systems in remote or regional areas than it does in some closely populated urban areas, and that is why the exemption is there.

In 1991, when the legislation that we are talking about came to the parliament, it was put forward by the current Leader of the Opposition when he was the minister. Again, in an interesting twist of irony—and there seem to be a few of those—I was the opposition spokesman on that occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did a search on that today.

—Yes, I thought you might have done a search on that today and I bet you did not find anything that I said that was inconsistent with what I said today. SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that no political party has ever sought to guarantee that after 1 July 1997 people in regional areas will pay identical local call prices to those paid by people in metropolitan areas. That is a point that you cannot jump over, because it is provided for in your own law. In December 1995, the previous government released an exposure draft, which I displayed in question time today, about the post‐1997 legislation, which gave no such guarantee and clearly allowed price discrimination between areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —And kept the directive.

—I will come to the directive. The government's legislation reflects the position in Labor's exposure draft, and that was the point I made in the answer today. I can guarantee—and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) did this in question time today—that people, whether they live in the city or in the bush, will not pay more after 1 July 1997 than they do now. I refer you to the speech I made here in May about the current pricing arrangements with regard to local calls. They are currently charged out at about 25c each. Optus have indicated to the marketplace that they will pitch some of their local call prices at a lower rate. I believe that under increased competition we will see Telstra's local call prices move down. We have certainly seen that with the STD and IDD rates. I know the former minister would acknowledge that.

SPEECH.PARA: We are also maintaining the existence of the price cap regime, which puts a ceiling on local calls—you cannot charge above a certain amount. So there will be competition below that ceiling, and that is a consumer protection arrangement which I articulated here earlier. We are also maintaining the option of untimed local voice calls for residential and business customers. Again, the Prime Minister made that point today.

What the coalition is doing—which, unfortunately, the Labor Party refuses to support—is providing an additional $250 million through the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund to ensure that regional areas have access to the infrastructure required to drive the competition that will push prices downwards.

Let me explain the importance of that for regional and remote areas. What we understand, and what most people who look at telecommunications understand, is that the fundamental building blocks to telecommunications are the switching points. If you have got high level capacity switches and digital arrangements, such as ISDN—and we did talk about ISDN before; you made quite a song and dance about whether or not we would meet the commitments on ISDN—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not.

—That fund will assist, and if you look closely at what the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, has said, you will see that we have not walked away from it. This fund will make it possible for the upgrading of switches. I refer, for example, to Flinders Island, a remote area in the middle of Bass Strait which is part of my electorate. If they want to be part of the Internet arrangements—and this is in statements released by Senator Alston—there will be more Internet access points established through Telstra around Tasmania so that people can ring in at a local call rate for Internet access. SPEECH.PARA: If you want to have the benefits of competition, with all that that brings—and we have seen some of that already—if you want to see it in the local call area and for regional and remote areas to get the benefit of it, you must have a rapid upgrading of that infrastructure. Telstra spends in the vicinity of $4 billion a year in infrastructure upgrading. We are saying there needs to be an additional push in upgrading infrastructure in those remote areas.

The way we have calculated the fund—and some people have made a bit of noise about this—is on the basis of the number of people who live outside capital cities. If you look at it, you will see that a state such as Tasmania has 59 per cent of its population in rural areas, outside capital cities. That is why it gets a proportionately larger amount. If you look at some of the earlier speeches that Senator Alston and I have made, you will see we have had a constant concern about regional and remote areas. You might criticise Senator Harradine and Senator Colston, but they appreciated the points we were making previously. The figure for Queensland is 54 per cent, and that is why they get that larger amount, to address those problems, to bring those people into the mainstream telecommunications infrastructure upgrading, so that they can participate in the information age, trite though it is to say it. It is also important to recognise that Labor wants to deprive Australia of that telecommunications infrastructure. TALK.START.PARA: —They buttressed it.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow minister at the table also signed the instruments setting out December 1998 as the expiry date for the existing price cap regime. Nothing has changed since we came into government. We would expect to review the existing price cap regime as the expiry date approaches. The answer fundamentally is the answer that I gave to you when you raised this issue during debate—and there were some 40 speakers during the debate back in May. TALK.START.PARA: —Dead right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus, Christine, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the bills before the House today—the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 and cognate bills—are part of the government's strategy to produce an appropriate migration program for Australia in the late 20th century. Australia is built on migration, and migration has formed the character of our multi‐ethnic society. Two of my grandparents were descendants of German immigrants; two were descendants of Scottish immigrants. My husband was a migrant from Central Europe. And although my children have always been Australian citizens, all three were born in North America.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has attracted migrants from all over the globe, and much of our heritage has been developed by their influence. Economic growth has been stimulated by their contributions, and the same migrants who have made their homes in Australia have sought to bring members of their wider family to join them. Without its diverse and multi‐ethnic migration program, Australia would be a much poorer place than it is today, not just economically but culturally, socially and intellectually.

The purpose of migration policy is to develop both the economic interests of the nation and to look after the needs of the migrants themselves. Importantly, an economically strong Australia is in the best interests of migrants because this is how they and their families will become prosperous. Recently, the number of family reunion migrants has far outweighed those in other migration categories. The government seeks to restore the balance of the program by increasing the proportion of migrants with skills important to Australia's economy.

As the limit to the migration program of 74,000 for 1996-97—equal to the average of the last four years—has been set, the increase in skilled migration can only be achieved by reducing migrants in the family stream. To achieve a reduction in the family stream, which changes it from close to 70 per cent of the program to just over 60 per cent, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) put forward regulations that would have required sponsors of family members to be Australian citizens and for sponsored parents to have more children resident in Australia than overseas. These regulations were disallowed by the Senate on 7 November. The current legislation was intended to work in concert with those now disallowed regulations by allowing the minister to limit the number of migrants in specified categories, queue applications into the following year and prescribe a cohabitation period for de facto spouses.

The cognate bills roll visa application fees, the health service charge and the English education charge into a simplified single visa charge and clarify migrants' entitlement to English tuition. They also amend section 21 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 and the Migration Act 1958 to allow the minister to revoke Australian citizenship when it was obtained as a result of fraud when the migrant was applying for permanent residency.

BREAK.PARA: The opposition says it has accepted the proposed size and composition of the government's migration program for 1996-97, although the less than strong endorsement of the shadow minister, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr)—`we have accepted the government's authority and decision to control the size of the program and the composition of the program'—is so equivocal as to allow the opposition to placate those who want a smaller program and those who do not, those who want a change to the program balance and those who do not. With the added cryptic rider `except where it conflicts with basic human rights such as would be destructive of the rights of Australian families', the shadow minister has allowed himself the luxury of reading the wind on the migration debate before adopting whatever position appears politic at the time.

I do recognise the honourable member's dilemma. What benefit is a definitive statement now if it spoils the chance to join the Democrats later? While it is unedifying to believe that it is the Democrat tail wagging the ALP dog, it is better than believing that behind the shadow minister's decision to equivocate, rather than to take a stand, was the fear that he would evoke the ire, and hence lose the votes, of those on one or the other side of the immigration debate. By placing caveats on its support for the government's right to determine the size and composition of the migration program, the opposition can now claim to support the program goals while simultaneously opposing the regulations and legislation necessary for the government to put its program into effect.

PARA.BREAK: On the question of migration numbers, the opposition has not opposed the current quota of 74,000, and in the shadow minister's speech he came close to endorsing it. While the government's migration target has received bipartisan support, it is important to acknowledge that a large number of people believe that 74,000 is too high. While some of those voicing such a complaint do so from a fear of different cultures, they are a small minority. In general, the call for less migration arises because of high unemploy ment and fear for jobs or a concern about Australia's environmental vulnerability.

BREAK.PARA: We have not had a thoroughgoing investigation into Australia's population dynamics since the national population inquiry of Professor Borrie in 1975. In the face of conflicting estimates of Australia's optimum population, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies failed to provide an answer to the question of a sustainable population for Australia.

I regret that the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), who chaired the committee, did not provide alternative models taking into account environmental, technological, economic and lifestyle assumptions. We may have been left as much in the wilderness as we are now, but at least the wilderness would have had a couple of signposts.

We need a debate on population policy because, like Professor Graeme Hugo of Adelaide University, I believe it is fundamental for the long-term future of this country. It is within the context of population policy, which sets a direction for Australia into the next millennium, that we should determine our migration policy.

Much of the debate on the bills today centres on the minister's changes to the legislation which would allow him, if necessary, to cap the number of spouse, parent and dependent child visas granted in any one year and to queue them into the next. The minister does not do this lightly. In Australia we have taken for granted the fact that Australians should be able to marry the person of his or her choice and bring them to Australia as potential citizens. We support the right of an Australian citizen to bring in his or her dependent child or children, and it has been our custom to allow our migrant citizens to sponsor their elderly parents.

Over the past years, the migration program has become skewed towards the family stream—concessional and preferential—which grew by 27 per cent in 1995-96 to almost 70 per cent of the entire program. If the 1995-96 demand had stabilised, the family stream would constitute 76 per cent of our migration for this year. If growth had continued at the same rate it would be 97 per cent of the program.

Economically, Australia has not been doing as well as it should, and no-one questions the need to pick up our economic performance by expanding our economic opportunities. Our migration program should reflect that need as much as any other program. If we are to limit migration, there is a clear need to ensure that, within that limit, the family stream does not overwhelm the numbers and we continue to secure migrants with high skills.

Under the government's proposed program, spouses, dependent children and aged parents will still be able to migrate to Australia but not necessarily in the year of their choice; some may have to wait. For those who do, we have to regret their discomfort without embracing the alternative—that is, put up with an unacceptably disproportionate migration program.

Without the proposed legislation, under section 39 of the Migration Act, the minister could still limit the number of relatives coming into Australia in the preferential family category, although he would not be able to queue those applicants who miss out into the next year. By deleting section 87 of the act, the minister can, however, cap and queue applicants in all categories under sections 85 and 86.

In rejecting this legislation, the shadow minister seeks to prevent parents, spouses and children who miss out in one year from being placed at the beginning of the queue in the following year and forces them to commence again with a totally new application in the following year with no surety that they will not miss out again. Perhaps members on the other side can explain why they have adopted this position if they are, as they claim, interested in assisting spouses, children and parents to join their families in Australia.

Capping and queuing is a strategy of the government to reduce the size of the preferential family category. To reduce the pressure within this category, the government has restricted sponsorship of spouses, aged parents and dependent children to Australian citizens and has introduced a minimum cohabitation period before de facto spouses can be sponsored.

I wish to discuss both these measures—the citizenship requirement for sponsorship and a minimum cohabitation for recognition of de facto relationships—although it is only the latter that is the subject of the current legislation. First of all, I want to state clearly that I believe both are practical ways of achieving the desired outcome, and philosophically I do not have problems with either.

When I was 15 I asked a businessman from another country who was living here what he thought of Australia. His reply was a contemptuous, `It's a good place to make money,' with the implication that, on all other criteria, we were really rather inferior. He wanted to live here to enjoy the benefits that Australia could offer, but he did not want, or need, to take out Australian citizenship. That time has passed and now we expect more from those who choose to live here.

Citizenship brings with it responsibilities and rights and indicates a commitment to a particular country. It is true that dual citizenship has made this commitment easier for some than for others. But if, for whatever reason, permanent residents are reluctant to make a commitment to Australia by taking out citizenship then they must be prepared to accept the consequences.

On de facto spouse immigration, currently Australia has an extremely liberal policy, officially requiring no period of cohabitation. Most countries do not recognise de facto spouses as a legitimate category for migration, and generally those countries that do, such as New Zealand, require a two‐year cohabitation. We need to maintain the de facto spouse category within the family category to overcome individual situations where a couple, for whatever reason, cannot legitimately marry. But it is not incumbent on the Australian government to treat de facto couples as if they were married.

For most couples, the decision to marry is their own, as is their decision to live in Australia. If couples see this as too onerous a choice, then perhaps they should question the strength of their relationship or the strength of their desire to migrate to and live in Australia. With thousands wanting to migrate to Australia and unable to do so, there is no reason why we should encourage some people to come here as prospective citizens on the basis of a relationship that has neither been tested by time nor cemented by ceremony.

Although the three migration bills debated here today will be passed by the House, I understand that in the Senate the opposition will combine with the Australian Democrats to reject the bills, as they did the regulations, in order to bring a halt to the government's migration program. In opposing elements of the coalition's migration program, the opposition's strategy has been to use innuendo to strengthen its rhetoric and smear to bolster its argument.

On 7 November, in opposing regulations that would have awarded points for English language proficiency in the concessional family category, Senator Bolkus, representing the shadow minister in the Senate, accused the government of racial discrimination. Although English points for the concessional category are not under debate today, accusations of racial discrimination have such an unpleasant implication that it is important to take the time to refute the opposition's contention that the inclusion of English language points in the concessional category is racially discriminatory.

Firstly, English points will apply only to concessional and not preferential migration. Children, spouses and aged parents can continue to enter Australia whether or not they can speak English. Secondly, although English language proficiency will be of benefit for entry, it is still not a necessary condition, and an applicant with high skill points will be accepted on the basis of those skill points alone. Thirdly, although those who enter under the concessional family category obtain points for their relationships to Australian citizens, their acceptance has always been dependent on school level. It makes sense to add English language as part of the applicant's—

The minister, in a number of answers to questions in this place, has never referred to the true explanation. The true explanation is that in the last three years we have had the acceptance of two groups of people that were not previously expected to be in the regular program. One group is the 40,000 or so Chinese students who were accepted for permanent residence and the other group was the big increase in the special humanitarian category for people from eastern Europe and other places such as Bosnia‐Herzegovina.

We had an increase in those categories. Naturally, once those people gained permanent residence, a number of them would have been expected, would they not, to have been able to bring their spouses or their fiances to Australia? So we had this sudden increase. The minister comes in and says, `The preferential category is going out of control; therefore, we must cap it. We must bring in these new rules and regulations,' which effectively take away the fundamental human right of union for spouses, for a husband and a wife.

But these new rules and regulations also affect dependent children. That is an amazing one, isn't it? We are not talking about children over 18; we are talking about dependent children. For some reason or another, someone who has come to Australia but who then wants to bring their child here is told, `I am sorry, you're not allowed to do this because you have to get into a queue.' Can you believe this? Is this for real? I just cannot understand why we have got ourselves—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't understand very much.

—Here we have the incompetent minister talking. Why don't you look after your own portfolio? Why don't you worry about what you are doing to child care and to aged care? The poor old people are really happy with you.

BREAK.PARA: While I have been in this parliament, I cannot remember a measure of this kind coming through. The member for Hindmarsh asked what the difference is between the concessional category and the independent category. She was referring to another issue but, Mr Deputy Speaker, you have agreed that this can be debated, so I will answer her question. She asked, `Why is it that we are allowed to have an English language requirement in the independent category but not in the concessional family category?'

Do you know what the concessional family category is? It is the brothers and sisters and nephews and nieces. If you introduce an English language requirement for the brothers and sisters and nephews and nieces, what are you going to do? Aren't you going to discriminate between different nations? Aren't you going to discriminate between those nations where it just so happens that English is a major language or the major language and those nations in which English is not? Of course, you are. You are going to say that the brothers and sisters of somebody who may have been born in a French speaking African colony, for example, are not going to have the same status—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Greek speaking.
—Or even Greek speaking—as the brothers and sisters of those who were born in an English speaking African colony. What an absurdity. What an injustice.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor Party took this decision very carefully in its response to the Fitzgerald report. Because Fitzgerald required it, we said, `There will be an English language requirement in the independent category. We understand that if these people want to come independently and make a contribution as skilled migrants, then, fair enough, they should make the effort to have a knowledge of English.' But, when it comes to brothers and sisters and nephews and nieces, if you introduce an English language requirement, you effectively are saying that those nations which do not have English as the primary language will be discriminated against.

The minister knows this, even though the member for Hindmarsh does not know. She says, `What is the difference?' There is a difference. All of these things are very important and can be explained. She tried to make out that our opposition to the English language requirement in the concessional family reunion was some inconsistency, had no rationale and was an extension of our view. All that is absolutely false. She fails to understand the difference between those two categories.

What are we going to do about this? First of all, it has been mentioned that we are going to vote against this measure in the Senate because we consider it totally unjustifiable on human rights and other grounds. Secondly, in the event that the government thinks that it is going to make some kinds of threats on this matter, I can assure you that we are ready for all consequences. The leader and the shadow minister made it perfectly clear that we will not back off on this matter.

If you want to use this for some other political purposes, so be it. We are not going to allow a situation in the Senate where this legislation passes if we can prevent it. Who knows what is going to happen in the Senate nowadays? We are going to oppose these measures totally in the Senate. We believe that they are totally unjustified. As the shadow minister has already said, you can frame a fair, reasonable and balanced immigration program on the numbers for this year without resorting to these sorts of measures.

The capping power the minister seeks is a very dangerous power. It means that the control which the parliament will have over the immigration program will become a nonsense. The parliament has a program, a set of categories and regulations. The minister says, `That is all very well. I will cap this one and not that one. Therefore, I will get an outcome that I want,' irrespective of whether it has anything to do with the real intentions of the parliament on the immigration program. That would be a very serious change in the way in which the immigration program has operated to this point—at least I believe it would be, from my knowledge of the matter.

I do not think there has been a request from a minister for a long time to have this sort of power over the immigration program. By capping specific categories, we then end up with a situation where the program can be manipulated in such a way as to suit the outcomes which the minister desires. The minister has come forward with this, not believing a word of it—especially this stuff about spouses. He does not believe this; it is not correct. I have already quoted what he said and I could quote other speeches of his. He has a record on human rights. I find it absolutely appalling that he should come here and support this approach. We should have a more cooperative approach.

We have a committee chaired by the member for Hindmarsh. I chaired that committee before. We do not believe this matter is intractable. If the minister thinks it is intractable, why did he not refer the matter to the committee for an urgent report? We have had months to consider this matter. We could have had the matter considered by the committee. We would have had input from the opposition. We could have tried to get a genuine resolution of the matter.

If the minister is really serious and wants to find some solution to what he considers is a problem—I have already explained that, in my view, it is a temporary problem to do with special sets of people coming in at a particular time—he could have taken the matter to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration and said, `Give me a bipartisan report on how to resolve this matter.' This is not something which has not been done. I remember it specifically being done when we had a problem with refugees and refugee control when I was chairman at one time. The minister knows he could have done that because he was on those committees all that time. Instead of that, we have this unilateral inquisition from the top and these very difficult measures.

I want to refer to another measure: the so‐called English education charge. People who have been accepted to come to Australia under certain categories need a knowledge of English language. At present it is proposed to limit those without knowledge of English. Those in the independent category have to have a knowledge of English. If they get their way, the only concessionals coming in will be those who have a knowledge of English—only a few people.

They are saying that they want to get rid of the English education charge. Why? What about the people who are already here? Don't we have a responsibility, when we have accepted people into this country, to assist in the teaching of English? Don't we have a responsibility in these matters? Of course we do. We particularly oppose the English language charges. (Time expired)

DEBATE.TITLE: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1996Cognate bills:MIGRATION (VISA APPLICATION) CHARGE BILL 1996IMMIGRATION (EDUCATION) CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Billson, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to remark on the comments of the member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner. He is rightly enthusiastic about this subject, but perhaps he could apply his self-proclaimed expertise more in relation to the proposals currently before the House. I might further add that the member might wish to constructively participate in the debate on the bill before trotting off to an international agency looking for an opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: The three cognate bills on migration being considered here today come at a very useful time. It is a time when many Australians have lost confidence in the migration program because of the way in which it was operated and manipulated by the former Labor government. The former government discredited the program. Labor created the community's concern about the migration program and, once again, this government is left to fix it.

The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996, the Migration (Visa Application) Charge Bill 1996 and the Immigration (Education) Charge Amendment Bill 1996 are some of the sensible and measured steps that this government is pursuing to rebuild community confidence in the migration program. The measures contained in these bills seek to realign the migration program clearly with our national interest and, in turn, rebuild community support for the program.

Before making some specific comments about these bills, let me share with you where I view these things from. Madam Acting Deputy Speaker, I am sure you would agree that often your view of things is more influenced by your vantage point than the nature of the issue itself. Here is my vantage point. When Hubert Opperman, the then member for Corio and Minister for Immigration, rose in the House of Representatives on 6 March 1966 to deliver a ministerial statement that effectively ended the White Australia policy, a child had not long been brought home from the Albury Base Hospital to his older brother and proud parents.

While the 15-year rule period of stay requirement for non-European temporary entry permit holders seeking residency or citizenship status was being buried, a fibro house in Davies Street, Albury, near the cemetery was becoming the home of a new Australian. The new Australian was me—coming into an Australia that a minister from our side of politics, who was a great Australian, had freed from the White Australia policy. I know no other Australia than one that is and has always been accepting of and accepted by people who come from all around the world without discrimination to make a contribution to our nation and to seek better lives for themselves.

Through my experience from birthday parties at my brother's school, where the majority of children could not speak English, to the Malaysian students who lived next door to our flat in Carnegie, who often took us on outings and were our on-hand baby‐sitters, all the way through to teaching Turks at my primary school how to play cricket, and to my high school days, where I was surrounded by Scottish, German, Swedish, Italian, Dutch and Pacific islander friends, this is the world that I have come to know. I have been involved with people who come from all corners of the world. The richness and diversity of our community has always been around me.

Tina's and my wedding day, in a Greek Orthodox Church with an English best man and Scots, Greeks and `skips' in the bridal party, was a celebration of many dimensions. I was not so quick to learn that I was the `skip' my in‐laws and wife‐to‐be referred to, while I thought we were talking about the need to hire a cart‐away dumpster.

I know no other Australia than one that embraces the diversity and similarities of people from all walks of life and cultural backgrounds who have enriched, enlightened, shaped and brought great joy to my life. This is my vantage point and probably the same for all those of my generation.

I will share with you a story in the context of these bills. My parents were working two jobs at the time I was studying; they were looking to afford to buy a new home. The same thing was occurring in the case of my wife's parents, who are of Greek descent. They came through similar challenges and had similar values and applied themselves greatly to those tasks. Tina's father was trying to make a go of a small business in Richmond as `John PAP‐A‐KOS', and was active in the local Patra community, his home before emigrating to Australia in July 1962, where his friends called him `Ioannis PAPA‐KOS'.

Both families were working hard, going without and doing the best they could. These were the sorts of values that we all embraced. We were two families from different backgrounds whose paths never crossed until Tina and I met in a law class. These two families provide support, encouragement and a great deal of enthusiasm for both of us and they have a great shared belief in our dreams. We, like all Australians, are strengthened by what we share and delighted by our differences. This is my vantage point.

These bills seek to reinforce the underlying principles that provide for a migration program that allows for all Australians to share a similar vantage point. These bills are part of a realignment of the migration program with the national interest. As then Minister Opperman said in that landmark speech I referred to earlier:
Every country has not only a right to its own immigration policy but a heavy duty and a vital responsibility to administer it in the interests of its own people.

The then member for Corio and Minister for Immigration, Mr Opperman, went on to talk about how our neighbours shape and manage their immigration programs in line with their own needs and self-interest and for the benefit of their own people and their own future. In migration policy, the national interest was the key under coalition prime ministers like Bob Menzies. The coalition government wants to restore public confidence in the immigration program, while maintaining the overall intake for 1996‐97 at 74,000—not dissimilar from the average of previous years, though the skilled category is being more heavily emphasised.

There is a sense in the community that, under Labor, ministers of the day took actions that many Dunkley residents would regard as inappropriate. Prime Minister Hawke's instant decision to grant residency rights to Chinese students present in Australia because of the Tiananmen Square massacre was a case in point. As Bob Birrell of Monash University observed in People and Place:

In all, the People's Republic of China nationals present in Australia before June 1989 and their relatives who arrived prior to November 1993 are expected to generate a total chain migration flow of 29,580 extra people.

I might add that that figure is somewhat different from the one the member for Calwell referred to. No‐one would argue that Australia should not be sympathetic to the individuals who have witnessed such unspeakable acts of brutality and persecution. However, humanitarian entry and refugee residency decisions need to involve a sober consideration of international hot spots, not mood triggered spontaneous declarations. The end result of that Labor government's failure to consult with its immigration officials—a number of whom we have with us this evening—and indeed its own backbench over the Chinese student decision has been a blow out in some migration categories, such as the issuing of fiance visas. More disturbingly, this sort of instant decision leads to other migrant groups wondering how the hardships and deprivations they experience do not qualify their nationals and their relatives or potential partners for similarly generous treatment.
The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) said in his speech on the second reading of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996:

BREAK.PARA: It is Australia's sovereign right to decide the total level of immigration to Australia. It is also Australia's sovereign right to decide the balance between the various immigration categories.

This is the greatest indictment of Labor. It will come as a surprise to many people in Frankston and Mornington that Labor never really had the formal power to determine the number of immigrants accepted in the preferential family and other categories. Perhaps this is why immigration got out of balance. Last year the preferential family stream increased by more than 32 per cent, with the number of parents accepted rising by almost 75 per cent in a year; while a 29 per cent reduction occurred in the highly skilled independent category. None of this is good for Australia in the long-term, particularly if it is camouflaged within an overall ballooning program.

The opposition and minor party rejection of a number of important management tools contained in the regulations disallowed by the Senate serves only to strengthen the need for the measures contained in these bills before the House. The regulations provided for a more informed self‐selection process for intending migrants, which signalled key issues that realigned the program with the national interest. Rather than rely heavily on this self‐selection process to manage demand, the Senate's attitude reinforces the need for the program management tools in the proposed amendments to the Migration Act 1958.

The bill provides for the minister to cap various components of the migration program so as to ensure the desired balance in the program is achieved. The bill also aims to permit the minister to fix an overall maximum number of visas that may be granted in order to ensure that the aggregate number of entrants is contained within the government's national interest goals. The government is committed to a non‐discriminatory migration program. It is essential, however, that the government is able to access more flexible means to limit the number of visas that may be granted within a financial year.

The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) seeks to provide the government with these very mechanisms. The behaviour of those opposite to oppose other regulatory measures compounds the need and importance of this bill.

We must recognise that migrants who do not have skills that are desired by Australian employers, including vocational English and qualifications recognised in our country, may have a bleak future. Despite Labor's claims, its administration was sloppy and poorly matched to the level of demand for occupations. For instance, in 1994‐95, 264 secondary school teachers were allowed into Australia as independent category settler arrivals. This was more than twice the 118 who entered the previous year. Yet in our country we have a large oversupply of secondary school teachers, with the exception of mathematics and science teachers.

Labor also managed to almost double the intake of accountants over these two years from 294 to 558. That certainly did not help the Labor Party to manage its own budget dilemmas. Many of these accountants have qualifications that are unusable in Australia, but perhaps usable in the former government as it tried to manage its budget deficits.

Given this government's dissolution of Labor's aNiMaLS propaganda machine, why would we need 178 more public relations officers, up from the 65 two years previous? These facts give foundation to the community's concern that the previous Labor government mismanaged the program. The coalition has had to restore an emphasis to the skilled migration categories, because the unemployment rate for some non‐skills tested entrants is over 80 per cent, but for some subsets of business migrants it is under five per cent.

Longitudinal studies have found that the unemployment rate of independent migrants who are skills tested is 11 per cent after 18 months, with nine out of 10 participating in the labour market. With a 52 per cent participation rate, preferential family entrants have an unemployment rate of 20 per cent. In 1995‐96, under Labor's migration program, five out of every eight applicants entered Australia without their skills being tested. This creates difficulties for our country as the years progress.

The Howard government's new emphasis on the skilled categories of migration will overcome some of the numerous problems created by Labor. The financial year that ended in June saw a drop of 6,300 in successful applicants accepted under skilled categories. In 1994‐95, the skilled migrant intake had comprised 39.7 per cent of all applicants. Last year, the figure fell to only 29.2 per cent, not high enough for a nation like ours which has needs in infrastructure development, in science and technology and in general research and development.

The only option currently available to the government to contain migration demands involves terminating lodged applications. The opportunity to queue valid applications and carry them over to future years becomes available with the passage of these bills. This is a fairer and more equitable arrangement that will avoid our posts being besieged by intending applicants at the commencement of a new intake year as if it were an offshore version of Frankston Myer's post-Christmas sale.

The government is also determined to enhance the integrity of the migration program. The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) seeks to enforce and uphold the conditions and circumstances that permit migrants to enter this country. Again, this is a national interest and confidence building measure. As Minister Opperman said in the memorable speech which I mentioned earlier:
No responsible government condones illegality or deceit, which are poor gateways indeed for the entry of new settlers.

Many prospective migrants play by the rules. I pay tribute to the hardworking Italian and Greek migrants in my Dunkley electorate who arrived here legally, as I do to the 10 per cent of Dunkley by the bay's population who were born in the United Kingdom or Ireland. However, they are quite outspoken against those migrants who do not respect Australia's migration policy.

Take, for example, the issue of sham marriages. In a Sydney District Court case heard earlier this year, Chinese citizens who took part in arranged but completely loveless marriages of convenience have paid up to $16,000 to immigration consultants and marriage celebrants here to defraud Commonwealth law.

While I stress that many marriages between Australians and foreigners are genuine and lead to happy, successful and loving relationships, the government's move to introduce a two‐year cohabitation requirement for de facto relationships will assist in rectifying a related problem. As Bob Birrell pointed out in another issue of People and Place in 1995:
. . . (Under Labor) Australia continues with its practice (not found with any other western country) of allowing de facto spouses to be approved for permanent residence. . .

Evidence shows that those couples who do not marry and who apply to migrate sometimes turn out to be engaging in a false or deliberately short‐term relationship to gain entry to our country. Migrant marital breakdowns involve many costs that regrettably have to be borne by other Australians. Sadly, under Labor, high numbers of spouse arrivals from countries such as Turkey, Lebanon and Vietnam have been dependent on unemployment benefits. The minister in his second reading speech pointed to an evaluation of onshore spouse applications which highlighted the extent of relationship breakdowns during migration application processes.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got a two‐year probationary period.

—The two‐year cohabitation requirement—thank you for the interjection—will provide clear demonstration of the necessary long‐term commitment and should present no impediment to bona fide relationships. Appropriate exemptions, such as for couples with children, have been incorporated. These provisions are considerably more accommodating than those administered by other major migrant receiving countries like the US, Germany, France, the UK and New Zealand.
—What about Canada?

—And Canada. You get extra points in Canada; thank you for that further interjection. The provisions in the bill will enable the government to deprive an individual of Australian citizenship if he or she is later found to have obtained this origi nal grant by fraudulent means. The bill proposes to extend the government's avenues to deprive citizenship where it has been obtained following fraud, without time limitations, during migration or application for citizenship.

BREAK.PARA: I believe that this measure will have overwhelming community support, not just from citizens but from both permanent and temporary residents. The latter two groups know that citizenship of any country is an honour and a privilege. The coalition seeks to restore true meaning to the pledge that new citizens give to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your election platform?

—The bill and the accompanying visa application and education charge bills seek to implement the coalition's election commitment—thank you again for the interjection—to more fully recover the cost of administering the immigration program.

BREAK.PARA: Essentially, two changes are proposed. The first change will fold the separate health services charge and English education charge into a single, simplified visa application fee that will encompass all charges associated with the immigration process. The second change will permit the government to more fully recover the cost of visa services. This measure will significantly reduce the cross‐subsidisation of migration costs by the Australian taxpayer.

If prospective migrants applied offshore under Labor, they did not have to pay any charge for English language tuition. So, not unnaturally, onshore applicants began applying offshore. The coalition government's set of bills ends this anomaly, ensuring that the English education charge is incorporated into a single visa application charge.

Importantly, the bill incorporates enabling provisions for an English education charge of up to $5,500, with the details to be worked through with the development of implementation regulations. The ceiling reflects the estimated actual cost of providing language tuition to migrants who do not have functional English.

The Immigration (Education) Charge Amendment Bill is sound and necessary. Both extensive argument and anecdotal evidence now show that better English language skills are of great use to both employers and employees. Migrants who take these classes show a substantial return over the years following their arrival. While migrants are unable to converse in English, they are unable to be full citizens in the real sense of the word, to function within and contribute wholeheartedly to our nation.

The government has carefully balanced this user‐pays charge introduction with an additional $17.6 million over four years for English language training through the adult migrant education program. In 1996‐97 AMEP funding is being increased to $76.3 million. Intending migrants with functional English, refugee, humanitarian and preferential clients will continue to remain totally exempt from this English education charge. The government expects that fewer than 3,000 individuals will be affected by this change, since more than nine out of every 10 individuals who receive English education through this scheme pay a concessional charge. The government's proposals do not fully recover the cost of immigration and migrant settlement services but will substantially increase the proportion of these costs funded by the direct beneficiaries. Regrettably, the member for Denison (Mr Kerr) engaged in petty politics and name calling around these matters, in vivid contrast to the constructive approach adopted by our side of the House when in opposition. Labor wants to micro‐manage the migration program and impede the government's program of sensible, practical reform and a modest reduction in the size of the program.
Mr Kerr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —At least more recently we have seen some encouraging signs, despite the noise from across the table, from the member for Denison that he may be prepared to work more constructively with the government to tidy up the mess left by Labor.

BREAK.PARA: Similar to many other aspects of migration legislation, amendments introduced by the former government with the cooperation of this side of politics had enabling provisions which provided more flexibility and improved the management of the migration program. A constructive approach would be for those opposite to support these bills and take up any legitimate concerns when the regulations were being developed.

The visa charge provisions are enabling and the actual fees will be set by regulation. The de facto cohabitation measures are enabling provisions, with the details to be set out by regulation. This is a familiar approach to migration legislation. The ALP used it, but now seeks to deny this approach to the government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate on the migration bills ends the charade and ends the double play—the two sides of the fence; telling one part of the community one story and another part of the community another story. The months those now in government spent undermining our immigration program are encapsulated quite nicely in the government's policy statement of February, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Coalition will also re‐establish the credibility and accountability of immigration administration and procedure to restore community confidence in its implementation.

The fact is that they were the ones undermining confidence. They were the ones out there day in and day out bagging migrants and migrant communities to other communities. At the same time, they were telling migrant communities a different story.

The current Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) sat with me day after day on public hearings inquiring into migrant access and equity. There would not have been a person who was more supportive of those people from overseas and who wanted more hours of English language courses provided free to people from non-English speaking backgrounds. We heard this day after day after day. It is funny how the rhetoric has changed now that he is a minister.

This does all come together because eventually they have to pull it together somehow. Here we are post-budget with the usual log jam of legislation. The draftsmen are too busy. We have legislation about doctors, for example, getting postponed for weeks and weeks because there has not been time to get it drafted. What do we find gets priority in the drafting process? What do we find jumps the queue and gets into the House in October? Legislation to limit the number of spouses who can come to Australia. This is the biggest shift in attitude to immigration that this country has seen for a very long time.

This government wants to say to Australians: `If you marry someone from overseas, don't be sure of living in this country.' Mind you, perhaps they cannot live in the spouse's country either. That is a huge change. Why are these migration bills so important? It is not budget legislation. These bills have nothing to do with the budget. There are no savings in here. It is simply about social engineering. It is simply about the government playing to the audience it created.

The government is setting out to prove that there was a rort and it is correcting it. Even the minister has the audacity to talk about fake marriages in his speech. He knows, I know and we all know that there is not one thing in these bills that will correct fake marriages. Putting a cap on spouses will not stop fake marriages, in fact it probably does the opposite.

The people who are cheating are probably the best informed, are in there first and know it better than anyone else. The person who will get caught by this measure will be the genuine Australian who falls in love and gets married, assuming they can bring their spouse home. That has been a reasonable assumption for all of this century. Not just since Federation or not just since 1949, but for all of this century it has been reasonable for Australians to assume that, if they marry someone, they can bring them home.

We have heard speaker after speaker opposite saying that that is a wrong assumption. `Why should anybody assume that? What is more, it is a rort.' This legislation does nothing about those who may seek to cheat. If it did, I would be in there supporting it because, as a local member, I spend a lot of my time dealing with these kinds of cases. It is important that people do not cheat.

BREAK.PARA: At the same time, the word has gone out to our posts overseas. Most of us deal with our overseas posts in person, by phone or by correspondence. Now I am finding that overseas posts are advising my constituents to marry because, if they do not get married, they will not get here. That advice has been given on more than one occasion to constituents of mine who are now marrying people because they have been forced to by the department. The advisers and the department were listening, so should the minister. That is what is happening.

I go further to the topic of fiancees. I was advised by a post a few months back when this cap came in—and it was not my constituent—that it had a case involving a pregnant woman and it had already reached the quota for fiancees. She has to wait until next July. This is the kind of morality and attitude of this government.

The filters are up now in a major way around the world. I was talking to Cairo a few weeks back about the brother of a businessman in Newcastle who is a Moroccan. This brother applied to come to Australia as a permanent resident a year or so back and failed because he had no hope of passing the point score. The family accepted that, but my constituent has some young children who have never met any of their family.

The brother applied and my constituent gave an absolute assurance in writing that the brother would go back, that he could afford to support him and that he could afford to pay for his ticket. The brother was refused. I made a submission to the embassy outlining my knowledge of the constituent and of his reliability and credibility in the community. I was confident that that assurance would be met. The answer was very simple: `The profile of this applicant is such that he may be an overstayer; therefore, he will not succeed.'

The sponsor can appeal. I point out, from the sponsor's point of view, that the government is saying that his word cannot be trusted. The sponsor has said his brother will return, but the government is saying, `We don't believe you. He is the wrong profile.' The official in Cairo said, `No, we're not judging the sponsor; we're judging the applicant.' But who hasn't lodged the appeal? The sponsor. All over the world, in Poland, Russia, Europe, the Middle East and Asia—I have spoken to all those embassies in the last three to four months—the word is out: `Don't take a risk. Don't stick your neck out. Run the profile. No exceptions.'

In the past, when a parliamentarian said, `This constituent is responsible, reliable and will do what they promise to do and, what's more, we'll oppose any attempt to convert their status,' the application was always successful because they would vouch for them. That kind of reference to a constituent is not given lightly. We all understand that. But that no longer matters a damn because this government is running a different angle, a different line.

Why are we here tonight debating immigration? So we can reduce the number of spouses allowed under the program, so we can balance the program. Let us look at what the coalition said in February in its policy statement about the program:

Our goal, wherever possible, is to reunite dislocated families. Dependents of the family unit must receive priority in our annual immigration intakes. The role, and often necessity, of the family in providing emotional and financial assistance to its members will continue to be an overriding consideration in entry.

The coalition said earlier in its policy statement that the immediate family unit—husband, wife, dependent children—is the primary organ of support. This is Liberal Party policy. This is not the policy of the Labor Party, the previous government. This is Liberal Party policy being put into legislation where the approval of the parliament is sought to limit the number of spouses, to limit the number of parents in the immigration program.

Let us look at what that means. We will take the case of parents. We all know the rules very well. The parents have to be healthier for their age than most other people. They are the only aged people in Australia who have to pass a health test. They are prohibited from pensions for at least 10 years, and in most cases either they or their children have to have substantial means.

I dealt with a recent case involving the parents of a constituent. They brought to Australia about a quarter of a million dollars in cash and $35,000 in annual pensions, plus a lot of other assets. They will spend that money. They are buying a house—I assume they have bought it now—so they are consumers. They are spending more than $40,000 a year here. They do not require education. They do not require any services. They had to be covered for all their costs. These people are actually bringing money into the country. They are not some drain, they are not some massive liability; these people are bringing in money.

But let us put a cap on them. Let us stop them. Let us play some silly numbers game. Forget the quality, forget what is involved, let us just put up the numbers and limit those parents. Let us put up the numbers for the spouses who come to Australia and who bring skills—they are still spouses—or do we try to do a double twist on independent spouses, do a skills test on spouses, and have another category altogether? What kinds of games are we playing? Why are we debating this? We are debating this because it is a priority in the government's agenda of public debate. This is part of the game to prove that the previous government was incompetent in immigration.

If you talk to migrant communities, you will find that they do not see a problem with the policies of the past. These are the policies that previous speakers, when in opposition, endorsed. There was bipartisanship on most of these issues. The current immigration minister spoke most vehemently about the concept of capping spouses not all that long ago. I know he has been here a lot of years, but he spoke about it in recent years, not in his first few years here. He spoke on a range of matters but mainly about human rights and, more importantly, on the issue that an Australian cannot bring their spouse back to Australia.

The fact is that we are a country of isolation. We are a small country in a very big world. We have been great travellers. Our people travel an awful lot. Successive years of migration have meant that there is even more reason to travel as people go back and visit their families and the places their parents and grandparents came from. The idea that somehow the number of people who marry someone from overseas will increase is quite logical and natural. We are a country of migrants and travellers. It is not surprising, with the number of people coming here and the number of our people going overseas, that quite a lot of them should marry someone from overseas. The idea has always been that if you marry someone overseas you can bring them home. Now we are talking about a two‐, three‐, four‐ or five‐ year wait.

Last year I was aware of a case of a girl marrying a man in South America. Her parents in Newcastle were absolutely desperate because she would not come home unless her husband was approved. She was pregnant. They faced the prospect of their daughter having a child in an unknown hospital in an unknown town in a country they had heard of but knew little about. They went through enormous anxiety to try to get him approved in time for their daughter to come back for the baby to be born. There was a week to spare before the airline would not take her. Tell that family, `Forget it. Sorry, Ma'am, the quota's full.' What is the reason for it? To balance the program. To balance the program for whom? For independent migrants who have no family here, by this government's definition—a government that says it gives priority to families but is giving priority to strangers. Their definition of independence is that they have no-one here to sponsor them; therefore, they are independent. They take priority over those with families here.

PARA.BREAK: We hear figures about unemployment, but what members do not tell us is what jobs migrants are doing. They are in work, but doing what? The minister will know what they are doing because he went through the inquiry with me. Doctors are working as gardeners or as cleaners. Let's face it, this is not the first generation where we have deskilled our migrants. The number of skilled European migrants in the late 1940s and 1950s who went to work as labourers in the factories of Newcastle was legion. The number of skilled migrants now in Australia in work but not using their skills is also le gion—architects working as draftsmen and doctors working as gardeners or trying to get work as social workers.
