We had witness after witness before the inquiry in the last parliament. The idea of producing numbers saying that these people are working does not tell the whole story.

BREAK.PARA: On the other hand, where families are bringing out their relations who pass on a points test—which, as we all know, is very tough—the chance of their getting work in their profession is much greater because they are brought into the system with someone who knows how the system works. Bringing a person from overseas with no connections, no contact, is a much surer recipe for failure as a migrant than the alternative.

We have had this debate for some weeks now. We had the debate about immigration the other night to a farcical level. We had the minister sitting there, listening to speaker after speaker opposite absolutely misrepresenting the legislation. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) just a few weeks back claimed that the Senate's decisions meant that we on this side of the House were supporting the idea of people getting off the boat onto the dole. That expression was used last week by those opposite, speaker after speaker.

The minister sat here listening, knowing full well what was being done. And what was being done was to reinforce the scurrilous attacks from those opposite before the last election and since. That is why it is being debated now. That is why it got priority. It is not because it is a budget measure—which we are so short of legislation for and things will not get passed—but because it suits their purpose to have this debate. I just remind the House of a quote from recent weeks in the Sydney Morning Herald. On 30 November, Mr Ramsey said:
What's happening, effectively, is just another nasty version of the race debate.
And in the same article:
That's the way politics works, too. Now we've got new migrants to bash, along with all the other scapegoats this Government keeps coming up with to justify what's wrong with the economy.
Who do we blame next?

A few days later, the same journalist wrote another article in a similar vein. It is of concern to a lot of thinking Australians that we are debating immigration over and over—and what for? No‐one seems to know what for. Certainly what we are debating is not in line with the government's policies at the last election. It is not in line with any other standing position that has come forward. It absolutely breaches any attempt at bipartisanship because there has been no consultation and no attempt to consult.

There has been no attempt to rein in the remarks of those opposite who know better. I watched the other night while people listened to what was said. They were very clear the other night that the amendments about restricting access to benefits were not being opposed for social security benefits, for jobsearch and youth training allowance. People got up over and over again and kept saying they were, yet they knew they were not. What they were doing was maintaining the fiction and the confection. It is a very nasty fiction; it is a very nasty confection; it is a very nasty version of the same race debate.

I have been surprised somewhat at the willingness of the new members of parliament to buy into this debate. They have not been here for immigration debates in previous years. To those of you were not here in 1984: go back and look at the Hansard and see what the then shadow minister for immigration—Mr Hodgman, from Tasmania—was saying and what happened with that debate. Go back and look.

This is not the first time these issues have come up in this country, but this is the worst time by far. For a government to start talking about taking away from Australians the right of their spouse to join them in this country—when there is no evidence of fakery, no claim about forgery, nothing in the legislation that says that it is making the processing more rigorous—is a major change. This is not some trivial issue.

As for not reducing the number of migrants overall—simply balancing the program, as it is called—in the minister's second reading speech there is no issue about what the proper balance is. He does not say how many of each should be the balance or why. He does not say what changes the balance and what criteria he will weigh up in the balance. He simply uses these motherhood statements about balance.

He is trying most of all to imply that this legislation corrects so‐called rorts. He knows that it does not. We all know it does not because there is nothing in the legislation that changes the rules about spouses. He also tried to maintain the fiction that somehow this government is fixing up immigration. What this government is doing is not fixing it; it is ensuring that immigration will be kept a matter of contention for months ahead. As the migrant community, the academic community, read Hansard, speak to those opposite and start to understand what this debate about, there will be an awakening and an awareness. It will not just be Alan Ramsey talking in this way; there will be many other people doing so.

The government can run it so far. It ran the split agenda for some months. The agenda comes together and, when it comes together, it shows: it does not fit. This government is maintaining a fiction, a very nasty fiction. Tonight and in the weeks ahead that will come to a head. This legislation is odious and should be condemned and rejected from the parliament absolutely.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on these migration bills and to make some general comments on immigration that are relevant to these bills. If we go back 2¼ centuries in this country, Australia was 100 per cent Aboriginal. We had a wave of British migration into Australia, and the 100 per cent Aboriginal population has dropped down to about 1½ to two per cent of the population today. We became a predominantly Anglo‐Celtic population. That varied a bit as other Europeans came in and have contributed to this country. There have been some great names: Ralph Sarich, a Croatian, and people like Arvi Parbo and the Greiner family from Hungary. In recent times there has been a modest shift towards Asian and Middle East immigration.

BREAK.PARA: It is interesting to look back on these waves of immigration. With each group of people that came in, the ones that were already there actually resented them—and I guess that is human nature. No doubt, the Aborigines resented the British coming in originally. The British who were here probably worried about the French coming in. When those British people became, and called themselves, Australian, they were worried about the Chinese coming in in the middle of last century. In 1849, I think there were only 270 Chinese people in this country, but by 1881 that number had risen to over 38,500, of which, interestingly, only 259 were women. But the wave of Chinese people did not come to pass and the numbers dropped right back.

Then, ironically, we had Australians worried about the British taking over through investment in this country. Since World War II things have not changed. There were concerns in this country about Balts and about groups sometimes, and improperly, called `wogs' and `dagos'. Fortunately, those terms are disappearing from our vocabulary. Those people have turned out to be some of our best citizens. In fact, one name in the news this week was that of David Campese. His family, undoubtedly, comes from Italy and he has turned out to be Australia's most famous international footballer.

Then we had concerns about the Yanks, particularly with their very great investment in northern Australia. We had worries about the Japanese taking over through investment. Here I pay tribute to towns like Cowra, which, through its Japanese memorial gardens, has tended to break down that fear and prejudice in this country. Even Joh Bjelke‐Petersen—I know people have criticised him in this place—saw the value of Japanese investment. Who will ever forget Iwasaki at Yeppoon?

Then there was the worry—on the agenda in recent months—about other Asians coming in, particularly Vietnamese. What will we worry about in the future? My tip would be that there will be worries about the Middle East and people from there invading this country, the concern being not their colour but their different religion. Probably there also will be concern in the future about black Africans.

There has been a series of concerns like those but throughout it all the essential Australian character has remained and flourished, benefiting from these immigrants from all corners of the world, and I am sure that will continue to be the case. If I have a particular worry it is not so much about the immigrants; it is more about the importation of culture from the United States of America, a country I admire greatly but I do worry about its culture swamping us through television programs, et cetera.

But let's not forget that there are 175‐plus countries in the world and virtually all of them have sent people to Australia in the past. With rapid communications, rapid travel and with business contacts continually going backwards and forwards, we need mixing between the races in this country in order to flourish and survive. Australia today benefits from something like an $18,000 billion surplus from our trade with Asia. If we shut down our contact with Asia in any way, the ones who would be harmed most would be Australian farmers.

I was amused by a little letter I saw in one of the papers the other day from an English speaking person who was in Tahiti. He said that the taxis there had an insignia on the roof to indicate that those taxi drivers spoke English. He said that would be a marvellous thing to introduce for Sydney taxis. I guess that anyone who read that letter would have had a chuckle. It is indicative of how, in many ways, Australians of an Anglo‐Celtic background today have lost the will to work. If we do move from an Anglo‐Celtic background to a more Asian background, the fault would lie not with the Asians but with us here. The taxi example I gave is indicative, but there are plenty of others.

I come from a rural electorate and it is incredibly difficult to get Australian born and bred doctors to come and work in country areas. Asian people are lined up willing to go out to remote towns like Brewarrina and Wilcannia if we would let them in to work, but Australian born people are not.

The Chinese seem to have a wonderful work ethic that we would do well to re‐examine. We have had some wonderful citizens in this country who have come from China. We all know about Dr Chan, but there have been others. For example, there is Richard Chee‐Quee, who often opens the batting for New South Wales. He is a very popular cricketer, possibly the hardest hitter of a cricket ball in this country. May we have more Chinese and Asian cricketers in this country. The Chinese have contributed wonderfully to our restaurant industry, and I often think that, in many country towns, if they ever went on strike, we would probably starve.

I was in Singapore on a brief visit a few weeks ago and it struck me there that in this country we are losing many of the values that they retain in those sorts of countries. Singapore have a land mass 0.2 per cent the size of my electorate. In that teeny country they have 2.8 million residents. They have a per capita income 33 per cent higher than we have in Australia. If you doubt that, you only have to step outside your hotel and look at all the brand new white Mercedes driving past. They have an inflation rate of 1.2 per cent. They have an unemployment rate of virtually zero. In fact, they have labour shortages in most areas. They have an overseas surplus of $130 billion. Here we are with an overseas deficit of $190 billion. They have a surplus in a country with no natural resources; they even have to get their water piped in from Malaysia. It shows how we have lost our way in this country. If we shut out these people and stop learning from them we will go further backwards.

These people are small in physical stature but they are leaving us for dead. Their work ethic is quite phenomenal. It is something that we have lost in this country. Their respect for their elders is quite remarkable. They have family values, which our Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has spoken about in the past. Dare I breach a taboo subject—you could not talk about sex in the 1890s, in the Victorian era; today you cannot talk about differences between races—and look at the intelligence of these people.

The controversial book The Bell Curve, which came out a couple of years ago, said that these people are possibly eight to 10 per cent more intelligent than we are. I do not know whether they are—you could argue incessantly about how you measure these things—but on anecdotal evidence they certainly are not behind us. We have boat people landing on these shores whose children cannot speak English but who go into our schools and, within six months, top their classes. I think we have something to learn from these people in that regard.

The Asian born people who live in Australia permanently today make up only 4.8 per cent of the population. If present trends continue, in a quarter of a century's time, in the year 2021, they will be up to just over seven per cent of the population, a level that has been exceeded in many areas of Australia in the past—and I spoke about the gold rush back in the 1850s earlier in this debate.

The issue of foreign investment has also been raised even as recently as in the parliament today. Some people think we should stop foreign investment in this country. Personally, I think that is the way to condemn Australia to poverty and to going backwards. We should not be banning foreign investment; we should be strengthening our economy so that we can compete with these people so that we do not need as much foreign investment as we have had to depend on in the past.

All this leads to many lessons for us, not the least for our original citizens. The Aborigines, as I have said, have gone from 100 per cent of the population down to somewhere between 1½ per cent to two per cent of the population, but I think we are on the verge again of the Aboriginal people having the opportunity to bounce back in this country—by that I do not necessarily mean percentage wise but in taking a much more pre-eminent position. I think there has been too much emphasis in the past on talking about the injustices of the past, as serious as those were and as much as those have to be recognised.

I take great heart in the attitude of the new chairman of ATSIC. We should all get behind him and the new board and build on their strengths. I think Aboriginal people are superior in many ways. They have natural advantages with movement, art and dance. We have had some wonderful Aboriginal sportsmen in the past—the Ella brothers come to mind, Lionel Rose and people like that. There is also the innate wisdom of the Aboriginal elders, particularly amongst the female fraternity. There are great areas that we can build on, and I hope that can succeed so our mix of people in this country can change again.

It is interesting to look at the things proposed in this bill and see how they have evolved over the years. I was reading the biography of probably one of Australia's most famous citizens, Sir Donald Bradman, only the other day. There are now five generations of Bradmans in this country, but his grandfather came out as a 19-year-old from Suffolk in 1852. They were the gold rush days. In that year alone, 95,000 people came from England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland when the total non-Aboriginal population of Australia was barely over 405,000 people. Over 20 per cent of overseas born people of the total non-Aboriginal population lobbed into Australia in one year, 1852. It is quite remarkable. Think of the change in the debate that would generate today.

Between the Second World War and today—a period of 51 years—we have had 5.4 million immigrants to this country. As the population has gone from seven million up to 18½ million today, about six million‐odd of those were born here of that increase. If you look at 10‐ and 15‐year spans, you see that migration has been pretty constant. Between 1945 and 1959, 1.4 million were immigrants. In the 1960s, a 1.3 million increase was due to immigration. In the 1970s, it was just under one million and, in the 1980s, 1.1 million.

The highest number of immigrants to come to Australia in a one‐year period was in 1969‐70, when 185,000 came in. The lowest period was in 1975‐76, when only 52,748 came in. Last year, 1995-96, 99,000 came in permanently. Of course, a number of Australians left the country to give us a 70,000 net increase in our population. It is interesting to contemplate that the 70,000 net who came in last year came from 150 different countries in total—a great enrichment, drawing on a pool of skills and cultures from all over the world.

Today, we have quite a variety of people from all over the world. Last year, the main group that contributed was New Zealand, at 12.4 per cent of the immigrants. The United Kingdom contributed 11.4 per cent; China rated No. 3 at 11.3 per cent; Hong Kong was 4.4 per cent; India, 3.7 per cent; Vietnam, 3.6 per cent; and so on.

It was interesting that the 78,000 who came in on a temporary basis were actually business migrants who were coming out here to enrich the wealth of this country and to leave again. Our population has been increasing about one per cent to two per cent every year. I think it has been in only two recent years—1988 and 1989—where the births and deaths, the natural increase of this country, did not exceed the immigration numbers.

Today, of the 18.5 million people in this country, 23 per cent were born overseas. In 25 years time, on present rates of immigration, that will fall to 19.4 per cent. Our immigration policy, which has been in the news of late, is much more conservative than the one we had 150 years ago. We should not forget that. The immigration policy that we have today is proudly non-discriminatory. It is non-discriminatory on ethnic origin, sex, race and religion, but it is discriminatory in other ways, if you like, as far as health, the character of the people—whether they have a criminal record or not—skills and family migration go.

This government has decided to cut back on the family migration aspect of immigration, and I think quite properly so. We are a sovereign nation and cannot take as many people as we like because of high unemployment. In fact, it is like this: we have decided to wind back family migration to some extent and increase the intake numbers of those who can make a definite contribution to this country, such as those with business skills. I think that is a proper way to go in formulating a migration policy.

There are many other problems that we face with immigration in this country that should be debated in the Australian population. For example, boat people have been talked about a lot over the last 10 or 15 years. We have to keep that in perspective. Fifty‐seven boats arrived in this country between 1980 and 1996 carrying 2,654 people. From those people that arrived on our shores, there were another 71 births. You might be interested to know that, of that total, 1,901 have been sent back, 390 have received refugee status, 34 have been let in on humanitarian grounds, 62 have bridging visas, 48 have been allowed to stay on marriage grounds, only nine have escaped—I am pleased to say that the figure is not higher—and, on the last count, 281 were still in detention.

However, it costs the Australian taxpayer a lot to keep those people in detention, and most of them have been in the Port Hedland area. It costs $580 a week to keep them in detention. It has cost the Australian taxpayer $39.6 million since 1992‐93. In fact, of the 1,900 that have been returned, it has cost the Australian taxpayer an average of $5,431 each to send them back. If we are sending them back on an individual basis, they are sent in a commercial aircraft with an escort, which is obviously costly. If we are sending them back in groups, we have to make special closed charter flights. So this is something that we do not want to see too much of—boat people arriving in Australia. But it is a very difficult issue because there are compassionate grounds and there are grounds whereby we just cannot let these people in willy‐nilly. I think the taxpayers appreciate that very much.

In conclusion, I commend the government, especially the minister, for the changes that he has brought in since he was made the minister in March, particularly the changes that we have before us tonight to discuss. The particular aspect of English language tuition classes of one entitlement per person for 510 hours is something that we should all look at very carefully indeed.

When these bills, hopefully, go through not only this House but also the Senate we will have a more balanced migration program. We will have more educated migrants and we will have migrants that can make a better contribution to the Australian population. They will be able to enjoy their lives here better and they will be able to make a greater contribution to this great country of ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I make my contribution, I commend the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) on his speech—a very thoughtful speech which said some very good things about what immigration means to Australia. He martyred a bit towards the end, but I hope that the views the member for Parkes expressed are indeed the views of his electorate, because it would be a very comforting thing for all of us if people in the bush in Australia took the sensible views expressed in the remarks of the member for Parkes of what migration means to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: What the member for Parkes has told us and what we all know is that Australia is probably the most ethnically diverse country in the world. That diversity is reflected, in particular, for me in the demography of my own electorate. We heard in this chamber a few weeks ago a speech by President Clinton in which he praised this country for its attitude to multiculturalism. President Clinton said that he thought that that was the way to go for the world and that we were, in fact, a good example to the rest of the world. Parts of Australia like my electorate are probably very good examples of how we are an example to the rest of the world.

Forty per cent of the constituents in my electorate come from a non-English speaking background. The city of Canterbury, which is within my electorate, is made up of people from 132 different nationalities. It is those very migrants who have chosen this country as their home who will be affected, unfortunately, by the provisions that we are debating here tonight.

While there are many reasons for opposing the bills before us, there are two that particularly concern me. The first is the proposal to limit the number of spouses, aged parents and dependent children visas that can be granted in one year, and the second is the increase in the English language charge.

Ever since the 1940s Australia's policy on immigration has had bipartisan support in this House, and that is what allowed the program to grow and prosper. We started out with a populate or perish policy in the 1940s, and that has evolved to one which, under the Labor government, attempted to be a balance of skill, family reunion and business migration in a comparatively small program.

The member for Parkes mentioned that there was a net gain of about 70,000 immigrants last year. That is not a country being overtaken, as some other members of this House would have us believe in some of the more rabid speeches that we have heard on these bills earlier today. Seventy thousand is a modest number of people to add to a growing country like Australia. A very important part of that balanced program has allowed us to see families come here to be reunited with the rest of their families and help themselves through the maze of settlement.

The bipartisan approach which we have had in the past was never better illustrated than in the era of the Fraser government, when the Liberal Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in that government, Ian Macphee, and shadow minister Mick Young both actively campaigned in favour of Australia supporting the intake of Asian refugees. We took in 90,000 refugees under the refugee program that those two gentlemen campaigned for. It was a hard thing for them to convince some of their colleagues of. In the end, I think it was something that we, as people living in this part of the world, had an obligation to do. We also had an obligation to do that for humanitarian reasons that we as a well‐fed, wealthy, developed country recognised.

Unfortunately, we have seen the bipartisan support that we had in the 1970s and 1980s, right back to the 1940s, severely tested in recent times. It seems that the government is content to use some of the jingoistic and anti-migration campaigns that are being mounted by some people as a smokescreen for its own efforts, which will see migrants, unfortunately, if some of the things in this bill are successful, pushed into an underclass in Australian society.

As the member for Parkes said earlier, immigration has helped to make Australia more culturally diverse, more tolerant and a more optimistic and forward looking society. He mentioned the importance of Asia to Australia as a market for our farm products. It would be interesting to understand that, for farmers, that market is becoming more important. Without that market, there would be a reduction in the standard of living of all of us in this country. Economic arguments aside, the fact that this diversity is good for us is enough to justify the contributions that migrants have made to Australia's national interest.

Migrants generate more demand for goods and services which, in the end, creates more employment opportunities than the number of jobs which new migrants can fill. So, out of migration into Australia, there is a net plus in jobs. It is just wrong for people to think that migration takes away jobs from Australians. The reality is that most new migrants tend to do the jobs that people who are already living in this country will not do.

One of the most telling examples of that was some years ago, when I visited a factory—it was in my electorate then but is now in the electorate of the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese), down at south Marrickville—which was a big forge shop. It was a dirty place, with noise and dust and heat. The people who ran that factory said that you could tell who the latest wave of migrants were, because they were the only people who would do this hard, dusty, unclean work. They said that, if they had to rely on people staying in those jobs for a long while, they would have to close that business, and that was a very big exporting business for Australia. The people who manned the forge works, which was the central characteristic of that business, were those in the latest wave of migrants. So to say that immigrants take the jobs of Australians is pretty silly.

Immigration is also important to improve the quality of life of those of us who live in this country. Living in a multicultural environment enriches all the population groups in that environment. With multiculturalism comes an exposure to other people's thoughts, language and food. As I said earlier, all of that creates economic benefit for Australians.
At a meeting of the Advisory Council on Multicultural Affairs in 1987, then Prime Minister Bob Hawke said:

BREAK.PARA: Australia has been immeasurably enriched by the contribution of immigration to our national life and by the success of the immigration program. It is one of our nation's greatest achievements that people have been accepted from a wide and diverse range of backgrounds, race, religion and culture.

I think Australia can look the world in the face and say—and people in my electorate are a living example of this—that people have come from countries all over the world and they have put aside their differences here. They have put aside their differences very quickly. In my electorate, we have people from Cyprus, both Greeks and Turks, living in the same street but not arguing with each other like they would have been in Cyprus. You have people from Lebanon of both the Christian and the Muslim faith living in the same streets and sending their children to the same schools, but not fighting with each other and killing each other like they would have been in Lebanon a few years ago.

Australia was one of those very significant examples of how people could live together, even 100 years ago. There is one great rift in the Anglo-Saxon culture that people do not talk about so much in this country but, for people who live in Europe and in Ireland in particular, it is blatantly obvious that the Irish were busy killing each other for hundreds of years in that country. When the Irish and the English came to Australia, they managed to find enough space in this country so that that never happened. There was prejudice, but there was not bloodshed.

I think space and the fact that Australians are a lot more tolerant and easy going probably has something to do with why we have been successful. Because we have a short history as a country, we probably do not have the prejudices of the old world ingrained into us. Rather than be afraid of immigration and rather than be afraid of other cultures—and some people seem to be trying to whip this up at present—we should be sensible and embrace them, because that diversity makes all of us better. It makes for a much more interesting, a much more outgoing and, I think, a much more successful country.

Both sides of the political fence in this country have said the unifying effect of our immigration program was that people should accept that we have a common language of English in this country and that immigrants should be willing to commit themselves to the importance of living here. They should put aside some of the problems of their homeland, happily share their culture with us and help to make Australia a better place.

Unfortunately, this legislation goes against that in a couple of ways. It strikes very much at the concept that immigrants should take on the language of Australia, which is English. In the past, we heard many members of the government say that English language skills were very important. The government proposes to do some good things through this legislation. They intend to spend an extra $17 million on English language programs over four years. That is reasonable. But it is no good spending extra money if you are then going to increase the costs of the program by over 100 per cent for those people who are going to use it. It is like saying, `Look, we're going to open this nice new school for people who wish to learn English in this country but it is now going to cost you twice as much to get in the door.'

In dollar terms, the fee for English language programs will rise from $2,205 to $5,500. An interim rise to $4,405 occurred on 1 October this year. I do not think there can be any stronger deterrent to new settlers learning English than more than doubling the fee. It is ludicrous for the government to say, `We want all new arrivals to speak English and we want them to learn English but now we're going to charge them twice as much.' It militates against the idea of language being something that binds us together.

I have received many letters from people in my electorate who have been attending language classes and who are now finding it very difficult to pay the fees. One letter was from a woman called Gilma Ramirez, who said:

I am interested in continuing with my English classes as I have found that my improvement in this language is of great benefit in my day to day communication with the Australian Community. If I have the opportunity of continuing with my English classes, I am sure my future in this country can be successful.

Another person wrote and said the advantage from learning English was that it would help them to get a job. They did not believe they would be able to get a job—in order to keep their family together—without being able to understand English, but they said the cost of the classes was becoming prohibitive.

How can these people have any prospect of being successful and of having a future in this country if their access to English language programs is affected by the cost? The sum of $5,500 is a great deal of money when you consider that most people starting out in a new land—if they are lucky—are earning $25,000 to $30,000 a year and of that they will only receive around $20,000 only after tax. If they have to pay a quarter of their income to learn English, that seems to go against what the government says it wants to achieve.

I have met many migrants who have settled effectively in Australia and who have said that good English language skills were very important for them. But the government wants to make it very hard for people to access those programs. Earlier this year, I was fortunate to present the Australian student prize for academic achievement to a number of young people who live in my electorate. The four students that I presented with the prize were either migrants themselves or children born of migrants. Those students were of Vietnamese, Korean, Chinese and Italian parentage. They were a shining example of what an immigration program is about.

In many ways, an immigration program is about helping to make the children of immigrants the shining future of this country. Immigrants—whether they come from England, Scotland or Vietnam—often bring with them some baggage from their homeland. But in the years that I have lived in the inner west of Sydney, which is one of the largest immigrant receiving parts of this country, I have found the children of immigrants to be the ones that highlight the great benefit of the immigration program. I thought these four young people were shining examples of how that program had worked.

PARA.BREAK: One of those students, Katherine Lieu, arrived in Australia as a refugee from Viet nam in 1979. She came here as a little girl. Now, some few years later, she is studying medicine at the University of New South Wales. It is people like Katherine who show that this program has been a great success because, by giving immigrants skills in English, they can empower themselves and be of benefit to Australia. English language ability is certainly a very important determinant in getting a job.

BREAK.PARA: The fact that the government has put up the price of learning English is already starting to show up in unemployment figures. In September 1996, the unemployment rate in New South Wales was 8.1 per cent. However, when you looked at those figures, the unemployment rate for people from a non-English speaking background was 11.4 per cent as opposed to 6.2 per cent for people who speak English as their native language. Now that we have doubled the charges, the number of people proficient in English will go down and those unemployment figures will go up. The government should not really pat themselves on the back for this measure; they should really admit that they have made a mistake.

The other matter that I think is wrong with these bills is the cap that has been put on family migration. All of us who live in this country would believe that one of the better ways to help immigrants become accepted and build their lives here is if they have the support of family members and if they do not have the stress of worrying about family members who might be left in the country of their homeland and who wish to come to live here with them. For the government to put an arbitrary level on the number of people who can sponsor their parents, children, spouses or fiancees to come to Australia, I think is really getting in the way of ordinary people's lives.

PARA.BREAK: Here you have a government that says they are pro‐family. Every day we hear the Treasurer (Mr Costello) raving on in here about their family tax package—their family this, their family that and their family something else. Liberal governments in the past used to wrap themselves in the jingoism and patriotism of the flag. This lot are doing that, but they are also trying to wrap themselves up in Australian families. It would seem that fami lies are all right with this government if they live here and were born here. But if part of your family comes from overseas you are not the family we want. We are going to say to you, `You have got to get in a long queue.' So parents are going to have to worry about their children; husbands are going to have worry about their wives.

BREAK.PARA: I have had the ludicrous situation in the last few weeks in my electorate where people have been refused permanent residence applications for their spouses. We have the Australian government saying, `We are going to let half of the family here and not the other half.' Then they say, `Isn't it terrible that people are getting divorced?' It is just absolutely bizarre. The government should really reconsider some of these things. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barresi, Phil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the coalition's 1996‐97 migration program. It is a program to be implemented by a combination of administrative, regulatory and legislative measures. I believe that the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996, the Migration (Visa Application) Charge Bill 1996 and the Immigration (Education) Charge Amendment Bill 1996 that we are debating today make good economic sense, restore integrity to this vital public policy arena, are socially responsible and maintain Australia's commitment to a sustainable immigration program.

SPEECH.PARA: After listening to the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), I certainly applaud his agreement for the diversity of our migration program and the benefits it has created for Australia. As a migrant, I thank him for those comments. I also got the feeling that he was searching hard, deep down to find something to criticise in the program—more political than of substance.

My major concern is not so much with the honourable member for Watson but with the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) and the comments he made earlier this evening about referring this bill to the United Nations for breaching sexual discrimination guidelines. I am concerned about that for a very important reason. We talk about politicising debate in this country, about bipartisanship for our migration program and about racial acceptance. I believe that the member for Calwell must seriously think about his actions and his comments and the implications that they have for Australian society. Does he really want to give those who are sceptical, fearful, intolerant and have a lack of understanding for the diversity of our immigration program an excuse to band together—a forum to attack and create even greater division? That is exactly what the member for Calwell will be doing if he pursues this course of action. I also say to him that many countries out there have the same requirements for cohabitation and de facto spouse arrangements. We are not alone in this measure; in fact, we are one of a number of countries in the Western world with this arrangement.

The migration legislation Bills is about a number of issues which I would like to refer to. It is about rolling the health services and English services charge into one visa application fee. It is about an entitlement to 510 hours of English language tuition to a level of functional proficiency. Nowhere does it say that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs should be providing English tuition to a level where the new immigrant can be fully competent in English. DEETYA then has the responsibility of helping the new immigrant find a job. The responsibility of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs is simply to bring the person to a level of functional proficiency.

The bills also provide the minister with greater flexibility to cap various components of the program, including the preferential family category. There is nothing wrong with this. It is simply an extension of the capping provisions. It is a vital provision considering that under Labor the preferential family program, which was set at 42,000, blew out to 52,000 simply because of the spouse component. Unless we have that provision, which allows the minister to cap the preferential family category, we could very well see that happen again. If that happens, where do the numbers come off? The Labor Party took them off in the business skills category.

BREAK.PARA: The bills are about the power to determine the number of visas that may be granted in any one year. They introduce, as I mentioned before, a two‐year cohabitation period for applicants who apply for offshore migration on the basis of a de facto or interdependency relationship with an Australian citizen or resident. They are about citizenship fraud.

The issues raised by this legislation, as well as those recently rejected by the Senate, go to the heart of the debate which is raging in this country at present. Most of us understand that an immigration program of high integrity not only is expected by the wider community but lies at the heart of our Australian heritage and is part of our national identity. It is important to demonstrate to those who are sceptical, fearful and ignorant of immigration that the short‐term impact of immigration is minimal and that the long‐term positive effects are great. In order to convince the immigration sceptics, it is vital that we include in our program a sizeable number of skilled immigrants, which this year has been set at 28,000 compared with the previous year's 23,600.

These skilled immigrants are people who can deal with the challenges of finding work in Australia without being a burden to the system. This bill will offer such assurances to most Australians. Once again, we are not alone in this measure. On 30 October, the Canadian Immigration Minister, Lucien Robillard, said in a statement:

Many Canadians were not ready to accept increased numbers of immigrants even though the country could handle tens of thousands more. . . Right now the Canadian population is divided according to the last poll we had.
There is something very similar in the Canadian experience to what is happening here in Australia. The minister then went on to say:
. . . while immigrants benefit the economy and do not take jobs from residents, many Canadians think otherwise.
We have to demonstrate to the Canadian people that this is a myth. . . But I have to recognise the myth is there. . . We need the support of the population.

That is the situation confronting us here in Australia. We have to confront the myth. We have to face the population and get their support on the immigration program. We have to achieve a balance and achieve integrity in the program, and that requires the support of all parties in a bipartisan manner—rather than trying to make political points, rather than threatening to go to the United Nations and rather than adding fuel to the fire that currently exists in those fringe elements in our society.

The opposition has publicly indicated its support for the size of the 1996-97 program. I welcomed this initial support and believed it to reflect a genuine belief that immigration should not be a party political issue. The government's proposal is after all about maintaining the levels of immigration established under the previous Labor government. The 1996-97 intake will be 74,000, a slight decrease compared with the previous year's intake of 83,000. However, the intake is substantially more than the 1993-94 intake of 62,000.

There is nothing the opposition should find in any way offensive in this year's program. The total levels reflect the normal ebb and flow of immigration numbers. It maintains the commitment to non-discriminatory principles and universal criteria. Above all, the emphasis moves towards the skills categories. This is a bill which will benefit all of Australia.

It is also well known that the previous Labor government allowed Australia's migration program to spiral out of control. As a result, it lost some important components—those components being balance and integrity in the eyes of the Australian population.

The family stream of the Labor government's immigration program grew by 27 per cent in 1995-96, coming to constitute almost 70 per cent of the immigration program. Let us bear in mind that the current government does take its responsibility to the family—as the member for Watson said—very seriously. That also includes the family reunification program. I am personally convinced that this program is extremely important to the long-term stability of this country.

However, we cannot deny the harsh reality of the family immigration programs under the Labor government. Under Labor, the preferential family component did blow out. It became an increasingly large part of the immigration program. If left unchecked, the migration program for 1996-97 would have reached an unacceptably high level of 100,000.

Furthermore, anecdotal evidence suggested that the family schemes were leading to levels of unemployment in certain communities that were unacceptably high—unacceptably high for any community in Australia. We owe more to those migrants than simply offering them a potential environment of despair where high levels of unemployment may exist.

It is for this reason that I would like to emphasise the integrity and balance that Australia must uphold in its immigration program. Those coming to our country must have a reasonable chance of obtaining work and finding ways to support themselves and their families in a dignified way. There is nothing more undignified than coming out here and being shackled to a welfare system when your dreams and aspirations have been blown out the window.

This is, I believe, a compassionate philosophy—one which says that our commitment to immigrants does not end the moment they have a successful application. They are given a fair chance of succeeding in their new home. Success is good for their families and good for Australia.

Under no circumstances should this bill be construed as a lack of commitment to family reunion. Of the 74,000 people who will immigrate in the 1996-97 period, 36,000 will still be in the preferential family program, 8,000 in the concessional family category and 28,000 in the skilled scheme. The government is suggesting a new emphasis on skilled migration, an emphasis which I believe will lead to a greater social cohesion and restoration of faith and goodwill by resident Australians to our new immigrants.

Those sceptical of the long-term benefits of immigration will find little comfort in this bill. Unfortunately, there appears not to be a great deal we can do to persuade these people that immigration is in the long-term interest of this country. But a unified approach from both parties would certainly go a long way.

For example, in response to the current public debate, the Asian immigration figures, which have been provided to me by the Department of the Parliamentary Library, show that business and professional migrants from Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and Indonesia are, in general, English speaking and more highly qualified than the average Australian. In professional managerial positions, they earn above average incomes. These people are providing a real benefit to Australia. While in 1985-86 they comprised 35 per cent of all settler arrivals, in today's terms they represent around 40 per cent of all settler arrivals. The Australian population has certainly benefited from a non-discriminatory immigration program which emphasises the need to open our gates to our Asian neighbours as well as out more traditional source countries.

Those sceptical of our program should also come to realise, as the member for Watson stated, that these immigrants do contribute to Australia and to its success. Immigration actually stimulates the economy. Every new person brought to this country is a consumer as well as a worker.

For example, when my family arrived out here, they had nothing. They had nothing at all, and what did they do when they came here? They were consumers. They were workers. They bought a house, a fridge, a washing machine, a TV set, furniture, a lawn mower and a couple of cars, eventually. Where did all this come from? The answer is that my family's possessions came from Australian businesses and Australian industry. It also came from sheer hard work and the perseverance of their dream of establishing a life in their new country. In many cases an Australian worker built the appliances, an Australian retailer sold those appliances and an Australian builder built their house. They also contributed to this country through having skills which were necessary in this country at that stage.

We should direct the attention of those sceptical or fearful of immigration to the Canadian experience—a country with a population comparable to that of Australia, in which the immigration target is between 195,000 and 200,000 in 1997. This is a country with one of the highest standards of living. The most prosperous area of Canada—the Western Provinces—are the most popular destinations of immigrants, many of them from Asian countries. We all know that immigration attracts prosperity. Let us hope it can continue within the framework of an intelligent immigration policy. That is what this bill will provide, and that is what I am supporting.

The government understands that economically this country has everything to gain from immigration, and the bill that we are debating today continues the tradition of recognising the importance of a strong, non‐discriminatory immigration policy. It is important, however, to demonstrate to those who have no faith in immigration that the government's policy is firm. It is about balance, it is about restoring the wider community's confidence in the program.

It is important also that Australia communicate to prospective immigrants that they must be serious in their application to come to Australia. They must harbour no doubt that they truly have something important to contribute to this nation. I believe that the increase in the visa fee will ensure that those applying to come to live in Australia are quite determined to go through with their applications.

The offshore migration fee is to be increased by $40 in this financial year, then by an extra $400 the next. The onshore family residence fee is to increase by $185 this year, by $900 the next, and so on. This will lead to an increase in revenue over the next four years, providing the necessary legislation is passed.

It is important that we communicate to the world that Australia is indeed serious about economic recovery—a recovery that has been thrust upon this government because of the inadequacies of the previous 13 years of Labor government. I believe this bill does send a strong message to the world that Australia is an economically sound place to emmigrate.

The good news is that the current reduction in visa applications has led to the cap on two visa classes within the preferential family category being raised. The cap on fiance visas will be raised from 1,500 to 3,000 places. The cap on independent visas granted onshore will be raised from 200 to 300 places. This indicates that government policy is working in this area, and the 14 per cent fall in application rates for the preferential family category, in the first quarter of 1996‐97, allows the government greater scope of raising the capping threshold. It creates that integrity that I was talking about earlier and that balance that is widely sought.

The bill is also indicative of the government's intention to get tough with applicants who do not deserve to be admitted into Australia. The government will improve screening procedures with respect to the entry into Australia of possible war criminals, people associated with organised crime, or `gang' members. Future applicants will be required to give an additional undertaking that they have not committed or participated in war crimes, atrocities or crimes against humanity.

We will also strengthen the enforcement of the provisions for the revocation of visas where they have been obtained as a result of fraudulent or false declarations. The Citizenship Act will be amended, where necessary, to allow the revocation of future grants of citizenship, where such citizenship was granted as a result of a material false declaration made or a demonstrable fraud.

PARA.BREAK: There is nothing draconian or unfair about these new measures. It really comes down to the type of person we want to see working and living in Australia. In the case of those who do not meet basic standards of honesty and decency, we have a right as a government, as a population, to prefer other people to take their place in a very, very long queue. The government has also decided that only Australian citizens will be able to sponsor people under the preferential family category. The right to sponsor family members to become part of Australian society is a privilege that should be available to only those who have made a public commitment to Australia by becoming an Australian citizen. There is nothing sinister about this requirement, certainly no hidden conservative agen da, no pandering to the populist view. There is simply a need to recognise a level of commitment to Australia's people and Australia's principles of democracy by those who are planning to assist other people in coming to this country.

BREAK.PARA: I conclude by adding that, in the recent debate on immigration, I have disagreed with those who claim that the level of Asian immigration is too high. There is simply no foundation to the claim that Australia is swamped by Asians. Currently 4.5 per cent Australia's population is of Asian descent. By the year 2031 Asian Australians will comprise about 7.5 per cent of our population. I refer once again to notes from the parliamentary library which say:

As the most recent wave of immigrants, Asians, along with people from Middle Eastern countries, are currently the most `different'. However, by the second and third generations, most migrant groups have integrated into the broader society, and the issue of ethnic ancestry has an individual rather than a broader social focus.

I ask those who are sceptical and those who are fearful to put those fears aside and come to accept the migration program of this government. I ask that the opposition take a bipartisan stance in order to dispel the views of those out there who want to discredit Australia's diversity of culture and its ethnic make‐up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding, Clyde, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with some interest to the contributions of the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Barresi) and the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Billson). There are certain clear and apparent truths in this area of immigration. They are that basically there has been a bipartisan policy operating out of this parliament for many years. But that does not mean that there will not always be arguments, both within parties and across the benches of this parliament, on what should be the level of immigration and what categories should operate within the framework of that policy. It is a matter of some regret to hear words like `racist' being bandied around in terms of the detail of that argument.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the honourable member for Dunkley that I do not believe there is a debate going on in this country in terms of Asian immigration. We have got one member of this parliament, speaking largely out of ignorance, without any understanding of the complexities of immigration policy, who does not understand the way in which that policy has been developed over the years. In most cases she is speaking without facts and with blind prejudice. She has received a level of publicity to which I do not believe she is entitled.

I do not feel warmly towards those newspapers, because many very impressive maiden speeches have been made by members on both sides of the House. The contribution by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) was barely worth reporting, but it has been sensationalised by the press. They want to run every stupid thing she says and then moralise in their editorial column, saying how terrible it is. It is time that some responsibility was shown by newspaper editors. Their responsibility to contribute to the development of a bipartisan policy is no less than the responsibility of each individual member.

There will always be this argument that is taking place now about the way in which the policy is being enforced. It is regrettable, but I think understandable, given the nature of this institution, that the two speakers from the government side who preceded me in the debate described the policies of the former Labor government as having blown out the emphasis on family reunion. I have no doubt that, in the case of those two members, if a Russian, an Italian or a Chinese citizen walked into their office tomorrow and said, `We're doing reasonably well but we want to bring out our mother from our homeland,' they would not say, `She's not really productive, she's too old.' In my view, they would try to assist them. They would talk to officers of the department, who apply objective criteria.

As the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) knows, there are officers working in embassies throughout the world who are under incredible pressure, who are working in posts which are described, to the minister and within the department, as hardship posts. The queues are very long outside many of our embassies. The great majority of applicants who come before them are given summary examinations and many of them do not succeed. To talk about a blow‐out, quite frankly, does not make any serious contribution to this debate.

Equally, some of the views that have been expressed to the effect that that can simply be dismissed as racist do not contribute to the debate. I have known the minister for many years. We have served on many committees together, including the Aboriginal affairs committee and the immigration committee. We have not always agreed; we have sometimes bitterly disagreed. But I could never say of him that he has expressed on any occasion a view that could be described as racist. I would reject any assertion that that is any aspect of the policy that he formulates or carries out.

I think the broader issues have been fairly fully covered in this debate. I am concerned about the reputation of this government—and, indeed, any government—in terms of our immigration policy. I was concerned to meet in my office two young Russian citizens, both highly technically qualified, who have come to Australia. They have a small child. Their application had been approved in 1995, their visas were issued in 1996 and they arrived on 1 April.

On 1 April, there was no decision by this parliament to say to those people that they were not entitled to assistance to settle in Australia. When they arrived, because they had spent all their money getting to Australia, they applied for a special benefit, and it was refused. It was not refused on the basis of any decision made by this parliament or by the government. I find it hard to believe that the Department of Social Security would have made the decision that they did. Everybody knew the direction in which the government was heading, but no bill had gone through this parliament. Yet they were refused social security benefits.

On what basis? It was on the basis, perhaps, of a discussion between the relevant minister and his permanent head, because existing policy is still in place and will stay in place until this parliament reverses those policies. The debate that we are having now is part of that process. So a decision was made in respect of two young people—admirable settlers to Australia, both highly qualified—who had to secure accommodation with friends. I advised them to appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Of course, having gone through the process, the department had to concede that there was no basis for the decision made.

I have heard speeches made in this parliament about the way in which we have a duty to see that immigrants who come here learn English and that they understand our traditions and philosophies. Although many of the people who come here cannot speak English, they are going to make a contribution to our country in the future; there is no doubt about that. This case is a perfect example of people who come here with rights and entitlements, but a decision is made on the basis of what is predicated to be government policy.

If these changes are to take place, then there is no point telling people who do not speak English after they arrive that they do not have an entitlement. If these changes ultimately become law, there should be no action by any level of government which predicates the decision of this House or of the Senate. In my view, that is almost contempt of this parliament and contempt of the processes of this parliament.

I do not believe those decisions could have been made without the authority of the minister. If they were made without the authority of the minister, then someone in the bureaucracy has got a very serious problem on their hands if the minister acts as he should act.

If we are going to make these changes, the important thing is that those things are explained, particularly in those countries where there are massive numbers of people wanting to come here. We ought to tell them in their own language so that they understand the range of problems they will confront, if they pass the test.

There is great tension within migrant communities in my electorate because the government, in its anxiety to deal with some of the problems that exist at the moment, is approaching this almost like a sledgehammer. It is evident in this debate—`everything the previous Labor government did was wrong'. The honourable member for Dunkley talked about sham marriages and about the rorts that existed in the system. Of course they existed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I referred to actual cases.

—I bet you have got actual cases, but he acted as if all were well in Dunkley. He did not have those problems in Dunkley. He would not get up in Dunkley and say that someone down the street had been involved in a sham marriage. He acted as if all were well in the multicultural community which he represents.

SPEECH.PARA: He also talked about his own background. I accept all of that. But, while he enjoys and responds in a positive way to the multicultural nature of his community, he also gets up here on a party political basis and says, `While all is well and I really enjoy this society, I am also bound to say how terrible it is that the figures have blown out.'

He also talked about the decision made by the former Prime Minister Bob Hawke. There was no doubt that that caused real concern within the department, but it was not raised in this parliament. It was open to the then Leader of the Opposition and to members of the National Party and the Country Party to move a vote of no confidence. Did they? They were perfectly happy, given the tension that existed around that situation and given the sympathy that existed out in the broad community, to sit quietly on the opposition benches and hope the matter would resolve itself. Now, some years later, they come in here and say that was a really rotten decision.

If we look at the development and the history of our immigration policy, no party can claim that it and some of its members have always been on the right side of this debate. The member for Dunkley talked with some pride about Hubert Opperman and was right when he said that he was a great Minister for Immigration, but so was Arthur Calwell.

When Arthur Calwell brought survivors of the holocaust to Australia, there were venomous articles written about that decision in the then Bulletin and a letter was written by a Liberal member of parliament which said that Jews really did not have any place in Australian society, they could not fit in, they had a different religion, they were not part of our culture and they should be excluded. I could show these articles to the honourable member for Dunkley if he is interested in seeing them.

The development of our policy has had these sorts of problems not only in the broad community but within our own political structures. It is important as we now approach this problem with a different perspective to understand that there have been very few ministers for immigration who have not had as much responsibility in the decision making process and faced the same range of problems as the now minister for immigration has.

We do not add anything to this debate by looking at the history of immigration and saying, `We have got a problem now because of all the things that happened under a Labor government over that long period of office. Let the whole process go to rack and ruin.' The fact is that all ministers for immigration carry a great burden and a great responsibility. In most cases they get it right and, from time to time, they are subject to uninformed criticism.

There is a level of racial hatred being developed in this country and the member for Oxley has to take responsibility for that. It is very easy to get a meeting of 300 or 400 people who share her views—the League of Rights will organise one. I have challenged her to a debate. If she wants a debate, I have said, `Any time, any place and anywhere in Australia.' It will not be accepted. So we should not honour in any way at all what is occurring in Australia as being part of the debate. It is not part of the debate.

The right of free speech, in my view, does not include the right to make hurtful and derogatory comments of any group of people who have come to settle in Australia and to say that they threaten our way of life when there is no evidence for that. It certainly does not include uninformed ignorant comments which are designed to build up a body of prejudice against new settlers in Australia.

I have said it before and I will say it again: the history of immigration in Australia is that the last group off the boat receives most of the criticism. That, I suspect, will continue to be the history no matter who has the responsibility for administering and developing immigration policy. In the difficult days that lie ahead, I wish the minister well in what is a difficult and complex portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent, Russell, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with pleasure to follow the member for Melbourne Ports, Clyde Holding, in the debate on the migration bills. I say to the House tonight that I do not come to this place with the passion the member for Deakin (Mr Barresi) displayed, the experience the member for Dunkley (Mr Billson) has with his approach to this issue or the depth of experience and wisdom the member for Melbourne Ports, Clyde Holding, has.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a pleasure to be in the House and to see two new members of parliament—Teresa Gambaro, the member for Petrie, and Phillip Barresi, the member for Deakin—sitting here chatting. I wonder whether their parents ever dreamed that one day Teresa Gambaro and Phillip Barresi would hold office in the parliament of Australia—the country they came to.

We raise this debate at a time when, as the member for Melbourne Ports has outlined, the broad community is facing some difficulty. I was recently called to a meeting of concerned citizens of Pakenham—it turned out to be not quite the concerned citizens of Pakenham—and there were 70 people there when I thought there would be seven people. I tell you the story because we still run a small business in an outer Melbourne area in part of my electorate. It was a very difficult night for me because a number of people in that room actually came from my church, came from my town, came from my community, and they were raising a whole lot of issues that were certainly not ones I supported.

It would have been easy for me, in a marginal seat, just to roll over and agree with everything they said. But I could not, because I represent a multicultural community. There ain't no difference in the blood that runs in the veins of the people who live in the streets of Pakenham, Traralgon, Morwell, Moe or any of the townships in my area. As the member for Melbourne Ports said, we do have some disagreement, we do have some arguments, on this issue. We do have differing views within parties and with the opposition parties. A number of issues have been raised tonight about opposition parties.

I found myself having to stand my ground at that meeting the other night. It was a great pleasure that in the ensuing week, after I thought I had had a pretty tough time with those people, people from the meeting actually came into my wife's place of business and said, `Look, we didn't go to that meeting to support your husband, but we are very proud of the way that he defended himself on the issues on behalf of his party and the approach that they were taking.'

I do not come tonight to pat anybody on the back but to say this. I have known the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) for some seven or eight years. I came back into the parliament and found him in a very responsible position, having to respond not only to the program put to the people before the last election but also to the position that he finds himself having to deal with now he has been given the facts of the situation. I have watched him quietly and with compassion. He has listened and sought out the views of many people, including the backbench, by the way, which is different. He has put a point of view and has put that into legislation, in a deliberate fashion, which reflects the influence he has gained in the short time that he has been the minister. I thank him for that because it is a most difficult issue. As I said, he went about it quietly. No voice has been raised by the minister or any of us on this side of the House on this issue, yet voices have been raised on the other side. That is disappointing.

The member for Deakin had some passion and concern not only for his community but for the broader Australian community. My disappointment, though, comes with the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), who, when he ran out of his written speech, had to say that everything we were putting forward was bizarre. For heaven's sake, I know the member for Watson would have been very keen to introduce a number of the reforms that have been introduced in this bill. We have gone out of our way to be compassionate and to bring forward a sustainable migration program—knowing that it needed some reform—that is acceptable to the Australian community.

Yes, you are right, we all have instances where people have been out of order. But is that not the same for every issue that comes before this parliament—that there are people who tend to rort the system, that there are people who do step out of line, that there are people who do the wrong thing? Should this issue be any different? I do not think so. In fact, I am sure that is not the case.

Mr Deputy Speaker, in accordance with your normal wishes, I will come to the substance of the bill in a few moments. But, if I can just take a minute, the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris)—I have known him for quite a while—called for a balanced program. I believe we have put in place a balanced program. We set out to put in place a balanced program that is acceptable to the community. We do have policies that affect the family. What disappointed me was that he had no yardstick. His whole approach in his speech to the parliament was that there was no yardstick, no limit. He never suggested a limit; he never suggested an appropriate outcome. He just went through all the downside. He talked about, as members do, `the one case I had last year' or `the particular case I had last year'. The legislation has to address the whole of the issue, not `the one case'.

It is disappointing that someone who is as experienced and has worked on as many committees as the member for Newcastle made remarks about not attending to the yardsticks and the limits that we have to put in place. It is our sovereign right, actually, to put those yardsticks in place. This is our Australia. We make the rules, and that is what we are here for. We are in government and we intend to make the rules on behalf of the nation, because there is feeling in the community—rightly or wrongly—that the former government did not get it right. And the new government rightly has an opportunity to address itself to those issues.

BREAK.PARA: I come to the remarks of the member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who just about broke my heart, knowing his passion and concern for this issue. I get very displeased when he stands up and says, `You are speaking to an expert on this issue.' Everybody is an expert on this issue and every other issue in this parliament. And he was wrong.

The former government were rejected because they said, `If you can't do it in this country, we are going to send it off to the United Nations'—for heaven's sake! The member for Calwell said, `If you don't do the right thing here, we'll send it off to the United Nations. We will get you on discrimination.' Yes, discrimination, or discernment? We want to discern what is right for our country, what gives the people that do come here the best opportunity.

I do not care whether you happen to be Croatian, Serbian, Polish, Italian: the member for McMillan is going to support those people in his electorate. Whether or not you have an English background, I am going to stand by you, especially the new Bosnian people, whom I have terrible difficulty communicating with because of their English skills—

TALK.START.PARA: —And yours!

—And mine—the Filipino group and the Irish group. The staff working around me even tonight—and I wish them all the best stuffing envelopes tonight—are from an Irish background; one is of direct Italian descent and one is from an Italian‐English background. They are good people, all of whom you would describe as Australian. But when it comes to the debate that has been raging in this nation, they also feel concerned and just a little bit threatened as to how the broader community treats not only them but their parents and the others around them. It is rather a serious episode; not one for us to enter into tears about but to consider seriously.

PARA.BREAK: Through the bill we are determined to—and we will—achieve the goals that we have set out to achieve. The bill sets out to achieve better management of the migration program. And, as I said before, it is a sovereign right of this nation of Australia to determine its own migration program. The family compo nent has grown disproportionately in recent years—1995‐96—and this stream has grown by 27 per cent, representing nearly 70 per cent of the migration program in 1995‐96. That is from the minister's second reading speech. Is it not right that we address those issues? Is it not right that we say, `Let us look at this issue and see if we can bring in some changes in the legislation that will effect a better outcome for our community'?

BREAK.PARA: Under the family reunion program, the minister has hitherto only had the power to cap and terminate applications. The amendment that has been missed by most of the speakers on the other side actually allows the minister to cap and queue family migration. The measures are less draconian than the former government had in place, allowing some flexibility. It is the same for children. Where there is criticism where children are affected, it allows the minister to enter in and say, `Here is an issue that is not fitting into the mainstream.'

It is one of the things that I have argued for in a number of areas of government activity. For a long time we have wanted for those in management positions—be they ministers, heads of departments or heads of certain areas of government—to have more flexibility. This bill does exactly that. It gives more flexibility for decisions to be made on behalf of `ordinary'—I hate the word—reasonable people who want to come into this country.

We are looking for administrative efficiencies, of course, and the complexity will be removed by merging the visa application fee with the health services charge and the English education charge to form a single visa application charge. The charge will be subject to a maximum specified in the Migration (Visa Application) Charge Bill. Certain applicants will be exempt from the charge: refugees and humanitarian applicants.

Can you do more than address those in the bottom 20 per cent or 10 per cent? Throughout this bill and all of the government's new legislation, we have addressed ourselves to the social issues of the people who are underprivileged or disadvantaged. There has been no criticism from the other side of this House in regard to that issue.

In de facto relationships where the nature of the relationship forms the basis of an individual's application for citizenship, the veracity of such an arrangement is crucial to the legitimacy of one's citizenship. This bill proposes to allow the government to make regulations under the Migration Act 1958, stipulating that applicants for a permanent visa on the ground of de facto relationship with an Australian citizen or lawful permanent resident satisfies a two‐year cohabitation requirement as a condition precedent to obtaining a permanent visa. De facto relationships are twice as likely as according to law relationships to fail during the period within which visa applications are assessed. This requirement is consistent with the coalition's election commitments.

An exemption will be sought from the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, for otherwise such differential treatment will amount to discrimination on account of marital status, which, of course, is proscribed under the act. There are exceptions to the cohabitation requirement: for instance, where there are children of the relationship.

According to department advice, Australia has adopted a fair and generous approach to the entry of persons on the grounds of de facto relationships. The US, UK, France and Germany have no provisions allowing permanent entry of a de facto of one of their nationals. New Zealand has a two‐year waiting period.

The integrity of our migration program necessitates decisive action where it is clear that the acquisition of citizenship has been tainted by fraud. The government needs to transmit the right signals about the value of citizenship. The bill proposes to amend the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 and the Migration Act 1958. The changes will add a new ground to the Australian Citizenship Act 1948, empowering the minister to deprive at his or her discretion a person of his or her citizenship where that citizenship is fraudulently procured. Where it can be proved that citizenship has been fraudulently procured, the minister has the right to determine whether a person should stay or go, or whatever else should happen.
