The time limits within which prosecutions needed to be instituted, either pursuant to the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 or the Migration Act 1958, have been removed. The provisions will operate prospectively. Any decision to revoke a person's citizenship on the ground of migration related fraud is subject to full merits review and judicial review.

I defend the right of any person to comment on Australia's immigration program or multiculturalism. As a parliamentarian, I am bound by solemn duty to represent all of the people in my electorate. I have many stories to tell about the people in my electorate and I would like to go through a couple very quickly.

The first is Tony Calabro, whom I met in the music industry. He arrived in Australia from Sicily when he was eight years old. His father had emigrated from Italy a year earlier to find work in Australia. Eventually, Tony Calabro senior landed full‐time employment at the state electricity commission before starting his own business in the township of Moe.

Younger Tony found it difficult as a child contending with racial taunts of `wog' and `dago'. But he became interested in music and formed his own band, after which he began teaching locals how to play guitar. I cannot go into his whole story, because I think he was thrown out of his first band and had to learn a few lessons, as many of us do. But since that start he has taught over 8,500 people in the area and around Australia. He has contributed on a regular basis to local papers on the importance of being positive.

As part of a recent LEAP program, which told the story of new immigrants to the La Trobe valley, Tony contributed by telling his story, which has been recorded for posterity. Tony Calabro is a very well‐known person, as is his brother and the rest of his family, and they have all made a major contribution to their area.

In the case of Shameen Rahman, she emigrated from Bangladesh in July 1972 with her husband and son. They settled in the La Trobe Valley in 1975. She says that she felt the racial aspersions cast on members of her family but not on her. Despite the problems her children faced and the family's struggles, she has opened a restaurant in the La Trobe Valley, which has been going now for nearly seven years. Far from being tokenism, this demonstrates the contribution that migrants have made to commerce and culture in the electorate of McMillan.

It does not matter what name you grab hold of—it could be the Falcon Soccer Club, which started as a small Italian soccer club and has grown into a national league soccer club—hopefully, they all play a part, in the minds of many Australians, as our population grows, be it with Indonesians, Filipinos, or whomever. If members care to get hold of them, all these stories are included in The Valley Success Stories: Migrant Voices to be Heard, which was launched at the German Club only a few months ago.

In finishing my comments on my commitment to multiculturalism and its benefits to Australia, I want to say this: we are most prone to alienating others of dissimilar ethnicity and values when we appropriate fear—when we appropriate fear in this debate or in any other debate that goes before this House. There has been far too much appropriation of fear and not enough praise of those people who have contributed so greatly.

This evening, in the short break we have just had after 6.30, I went down the street in this town and saw the variety of restaurants there. They are not selling just fish and chips and hamburgers; they are selling every nation's food. Every nation's food is appreciated not only here in Canberra but also in Longreach, Tasmania, Morwell, Moe, Traralgon, and all over the country.

If we continue to appropriate fear in this House, we only lead ourselves astray, confuse the issues and set ourselves apart from the community that we serve. From this date, let us move together not to appropriate fear but to appropriate the great pleasures that are before us in this country whilst we have such a great contribution from our multicultural friends. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The House tonight is debating the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 and cognate bills. In debating these bills, members should recall the strenuous efforts of the Liberal Party in trumpeting its virtues to the Australian electorate on the pretence that it would govern for all of us. But the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) is one in a series which shows yet again that the Liberal Party views migrants as second‐class citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition campaign of inclusiveness featured no less a figure than the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard), whom members opposite will recall in one television advertisement stopping to allow a friendly Asian Australian to catch up with him and engage in conversation. The message that Liberal Party propagandists, with the Prime Minister's consent, wanted us to believe was that that inclusiveness related especially to migrants. Six months later, the Prime Minister's attempts at inclusion have been shown up. Inclusion has transformed itself into exclusion.

The coalition government is less than a year old but already it is demonstrating that disturbing trend of U‐turn. As Arthur Daly would say, it's got form. This U‐turn on immigration is par for the course. Already we have had U‐turns on industry policy, ABC funding, the republic, nursing homes and many other things.

I will confess to being surprised by the Prime Minister's role in allowing a U-turn on migration policy. It is a political sore which he picked at in 1988 and which festered for several years afterwards. He should know better. He should know that the Australian electorate regards him with caution on immigration and racial matters. He even grudgingly acknowledged some six years later, as he prepared to resume the leadership from the beleaguered member for Mayo (Mr Downer), that his remarks were ill‐advised.

By finally acknowledging that he was wrong to say what he had said back in 1988, the Prime Minister attempted, with some success at the time, to relieve himself of an albatross. But, as these bills demonstrate—and as his half-hearted responses to the divisive demagoguery of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) have already indicated—the albatross is back. The Prime Minister wanted migrant Australians to believe that he could be trusted on migration issues but, unfortunately for him, this bill sends precisely the opposite message to those Australians.

The bills being debated this evening involve provisions which will impede the migration process. The bills include measures which are regressive in their impact. In particular, I and other opposition members reject the proposal to increase the English education charge by 250 per cent. We regard the learning of English as important, and I am sorry to hear that members opposite do not regard it as important. Prior to the last election, attitudinal responses of the Australian candidates study of 1996 indicated that more than 97 per cent of Liberal and National Party candidates regarded speaking English as critical to being truly Australian.

In view of that, and in view of the fact that the member for McMillan (Mr Broadbent) referred in his contribution to the difficulty he had communicating with some constituents of his who did not have English language skills, it is absolutely extraordinary that this legislation is in fact increasing the English education charge. It is skyrocketing the English education charge in a way which will discourage migrants from learning English and being able to participate in the Australian community in the way that we would all want them to participate.

It is ironic that a government promoting the virtues of efficiency and good management has handled its migration reform so poorly and so inefficiently. The sudden mid-year changes to migration regulations by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) have resulted in visa applications being rejected when either immediately before the changes were announced or immediately after the Senate sensibly rejected them those applications would have succeeded. My office has dealt with two such cases in recent weeks.

It is a terrible state of affairs when the department rejects applications without any legal foundation. There is nothing inclusive about these people being told that, because the government messed up the process, they now have to line up again and pay another application fee. There is nothing inclusive about the anger and frustration they feel. The only message prospective Australians have received from this government is that becoming an Australian will be more expensive and more onerous.

I also wish to comment on what I regard as one of the more objectionable aspects of this legislation—that is, the power that it will vest in the minister to arbitrarily cap the number of spouse, aged parent and dependent child visas that can be granted in one year. There is nothing honourable or dignified about this proposal. I would say to the House that the government's proposal on capping revives memories of that other infamous conservative numbers game—that is, the national service lottery. Back then, our defence and foreign policies were reduced to a game of chance. If you happened to be born on a certain day of a certain year, off you went. That was the numbers game that Australians learned to despise because it randomly destroyed Australian lives.

I thought that we had seen the last of Liberal governments replacing proper public policy with numbers games, but I have to stand corrected. In framing this legislation, the government has delved back into its gladstone bag of ministerial tricks and dusted off the national service lottery. There could be few things crueller than telling migrant Australians that, irrespective of their credentials, they have missed out—the quota has been reached, the gate has been shut, better luck next year. Just like the Vietnam lottery, luck, not compassion or understanding, is the key ingredient.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think happens now?
—It is a moot point, but if the Liberal Party's advertising agency were to—
—It happens in the independent categories and the concessional categories now.

—This is why you, Minister, are giving yourself the capacity to cap them midway through. That is what this bill is on about. It is a moot point, but if the Liberal Party's advertising agency were to invite Asian Australians to participate in a remake of that Prime Minister's street walk advertisement, and perhaps there would be a lot of expressions of interest, I guess the message those Australians would want to deliver to the Prime Minister would not be nearly as favourable as the original advertisement made out. If the real sentiment of migrant communities in this country were to be condensed into any public broadcast, it might well violate existing regulations on language and conduct.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's attitude to migrant Australians deserves condemnation. It betrays the message that the Prime Minister and his propagandists vigorously promoted in the lead-up to the election. Furthermore, it exposes him as someone who, although he might have admitted to earlier folly on migration and racial issues, has failed to learn anything from that experience, if his professed change of heart was in fact sincere in the first place. This is damaging us in a collective sense. This is not without cost, and some of the free speech that the Prime Minister has referred to concerning racial matters and migration matters is not free at all.

I want to draw the attention of the House to a recent poll of Asian executives which indicated that over 67 per cent were not satisfied with the Australian government's stance in the race debate. In South Korea, for example, it found that 80 per cent of executives believed that the increase in anti-Asian rhetoric had made Australia less attractive for Asian investment. There are similar figures: Malaysia, 64 per cent plus; Hong Kong, 61 per cent plus; and, Taiwan, 53 per cent plus. The most extreme result was in South Korea where 70 per cent believed Australians were racist while in Indonesia the figure was 59 per cent and in Malaysia it was over 58 per cent.

These statistics indicate that this debate and these measures are not without cost in terms of Australia's interests in trade, in business and in becoming closer to the Asian nations and the Asian communities. In addition, this legislation represents both an attack on fundamental family values and a repudiation of the coalition's pre-election commitments. The coalition said prior to the election, `The family unit is the foundation of our society and must be at the core of immigration and settlement policy.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Last weekend I attended two functions in my electorate which highlighted two important community values that go to the heart of what makes Australia great—namely, the values of racial tolerance and volunteerism. While the two functions were quite different, they demonstrated in their own way some intrinsic and uplifting features of our Australian way of life that are worth preserving at all costs.

SPEECH.PARA: On Sunday I attended the opening of the new building of Geelong's Filipino community. I had visited the premises in its early stages of construction when all that existed was a building frame and a couple of walls. The community was seeking funds from individual donors in the form of a buy‐a‐brick scheme and also some financial support from the City of Greater Geelong to complete the premises.

It was a pleasure to see the Filipino community gather on Sunday to celebrate the fact that, after much toil and effort largely from community volunteers, the building had been brought to the stage where it could be used for community functions. The fact that the Filipino community is able to enjoy these facilities is due to the extraordinary and dedicated efforts of volunteers who have organised materials and donated their skills and time to construct the building. My congratulations go to the community's committee which has brought this dream to reality.

The event on Sunday made a powerful statement about the sort of society Australia is today. Gathered were Australians of caucasian and Asian origin coming together to celebrate their collective achievement. At a time when some in our midst despair at the breakdown of family life, I witnessed a community celebration that placed great emphasis on the participation of families and of children. My mind wandered to the current debate on immigration and the sad and negative sentiments that have been unleashed by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) in her first speech to this parliament—a regrettable speech because of the sheer inaccuracies that underpinned it and the distorted perceptions that are generated in the wider community.

As I watched young Australians of Asian origin enjoying the celebration, I thought of how un‐Australian it would be for any of them to be victimised because of their racial background. Like most of us who are immigrants in this great land, they are entitled to their culture, to their history and to live their lives out as true Australians. More than anything else, they are entitled to an Australian fair go. The racial tolerance we have built into the ethos of the Australian community must be defended from the ill‐informed, the mercenaries, the bigots and the racists who pine for an Australia that simply does not exist.

The second event I attended was the 10th anniversary celebrations of the Anakie and District Community Group. Anakie is a small rural town in my electorate. The story of the group's community house is a really interesting one. The first house coordinator, Heather O'Shannessy, started her early days in the job with no carpet or heaters and only a child's chair and a telephone to commence her duties. From these humble beginnings the house has grown to become a meeting place for the residents, holding classes and craft workshops for those seeking to improve their skills and to socialise.

The celebrations honoured the contribution to the community of ex‐Corio Shire Councillor Ray Tucker, who has been the president of the group for the past 10 years. Ray is one of those dedicated volunteers who works tirelessly and unselfishly to build and maintain the bonds of community in his locality.

It is this sort of commitment by volunteers such as Ray Tucker that has enabled small communities in provincial Australia to develop and retain a sense of local identity amidst the global changes that bear in on even those local communities. I thank both groups for the hospitality that they displayed to me on Sunday. I was made most welcome. More importantly, at both functions there were encouraging signs that a sense of community and local identity are alive and well in provincial Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Forget what the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) has described as `relevance deprivation syndrome'—the overwhelming sense of depression experienced by the true believers in South Australia on 11 December 1993, as they were corralled into a wedge between Port Road and Main North Road, makes my federal ALP colleagues look euphoric. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of child labour has been raised in this place, but perhaps not often enough. It is an issue which needs to be raised again and again so that Australians are aware that in some countries children are forced into work in the most appalling conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: Somewhere between 100 million and 200 million children around the world are forced into labour. Exact statistics are not kept, and one must rely on estimates. Child labour is related to a vast array of problems. It is strongest in areas where there has been no land reform and where there is little opportunity and/or incentive for children to be educated. Any approach to dealing comprehensively with child labour needs to be based on the elimination of all these problems. However, that does not mean that the evil of child labour as an issue in its own right should not be addressed.

The ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organisation in Singapore this week is a venue where child labour should be raised. In the past, Australian governments of all persuasions have been reluctant to pursue the issues of child labour and human rights through trade agreements. I have long had difficulty with this position, whether it be from this government or from the previous government. If it is legitimate to include economic issues such as subsidy levels in trade agreements, surely it is equally legitimate to include social issues or environmental issues that affect free trade in such agreements.

The situation is now beginning to develop where Australia is standing alone against the rest of the developed world on the linking of human rights and trade. Given our excellent record of human rights, this is a very disturbing and unfortunate state of affairs. Australia is now at odds with the United States on a role for the World Trade Organisation in promoting human rights. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) made this quite clear from his remarks on trade and human rights in Singapore yesterday.

Furthermore, the government has refused to sign a trade agreement with the European Union because it contained a now standard clause on human rights that the European Union requires from all its trading partners. The Canberra Times said in its editorial today that both objections are difficult to understand.

This bizarre behaviour means that Australia is becoming increasingly isolated from world opinion about the issues of human rights and trade. Most Australians would be disturbed to discover that their government was not prepared to utilise every forum available to it to promote the values that Australians hold dear.

If it is appropriate for countries to reduce or even ban some subsidies in the name of global free trade, surely it is just as appropriate for the exploitation of workers and the virtual slavery of children to be considered as barriers as well. Free trade would be of no benefit to those in developing nations if their human rights are violated by them being exploited or forced into child labour.

Both the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) have said that the issues of labour standards and human rights are issues for Australia to pursue through the International Labour Organisation rather than the World Trade Organisation. This is somewhat ironic, given the significant downgrading of relations between the ILO and Australia that this government has undertaken. Australia has withdrawn from the governing body of the ILO and has closed the permanent representation to the ILO.

On the one hand, the government is signalling that it is no longer interested in playing an active role in the International Labor Organisation but, on the other hand, it is saying that it expects it to deal with important human rights issues. The only conclusion that one can draw from this erratic behaviour is that the government is becoming increasingly ambivalent about issues of labour standards in human rights and increasingly out of step with developed world thinking about how best to pursue them.

If they are not able to rely on their government to take up these issues, there is still much that Australians as consumers can do to help eradicate child labour. The Rugmark Foundation is an example of such action. In the early 1990s, German and American rug consumers, who account for the purchase of some 80 per cent of the world's rugs, became so concerned about child labour in India's rug production that action was demanded. An Indian export promotion association and anti-child labour groups formed the Rugmark Foundation. Rugmark certifies that a carpet is not made with child labour, and such products carry a label which is identifiable to the consumer. This way the consumer is able to make informed choices about what is purchased.

Trade can never be an issue which is viewed in isolation. Individual consumers and free trading nations should have the right to impose barriers on free trade for countries which do not ensure that trade is free for everyone.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise here tonight to pay tribute to a great group of people who are uniquely tropical North Queenslanders and who, in recent weeks, probably did more to cement Australia-US relations than our diplomats could do in a decade. It must have been somewhat of a pleasant change for President and Mrs Clinton to dine out at one of the Port's many world-class restaurants—the Nautilus Restaurant—amongst other ordinary patrons without any fuss being made of their presence, or for the President to take an early morning jog on Four Mile Beach with nothing more than a good morning nod from other joggers and strollers that he passed. It is so safe that one normally very uptight secret service member said that he considered Australia to be a holiday for him as well as for the President. I am sure that this is what prompted the President to remark on leaving, Macarthur‐like: `I will return.'

David Zlatarich, President of the Douglas Shire Tourism Association, and his equally hardworking membership, along with Mayor Mike Berwick and his fellow councillors of the Douglas Shire Council, deserve all the credit that can be given to them for seeing the opportunity which presented itself to them, reaching out and grasping it and turning what in itself was an extremely exciting event—a presidential visit—into one very successful tourism marketing exercise. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to raise the issue of superannuation funds and benefits payable to same sex partners. My electorate of Grayndler is a culturally and socially diverse community. In this context, I consider it crucial that a local member represent the diversity of their electorate and continually push for a fair go for all community members. The Gay and Lesbian Rights Lobby, the Australian Council for Lesbian and Gay Rights, trade unions and superannuation industry representatives have recently joined together to push for an overhaul of existing superannuation laws. In short, they certainly need reform.

PARA.BREAK: Thanks to initiatives introduced by the former Labor government, more than 93 per cent of full-time employees, 67 per cent of part-time employees and 59 per cent of casual employees are now covered by superannua tion. Unfortunately, while these reforms saw superannuation money flowing to more workers on the grounds that they were being wrongly excluded, all people are not equal in terms of the benefits they are entitled to when the time comes for superannuation funds to make payment to superannuants' partners, where that partner happens to be gay or lesbian.

SPEECH.PARA: Superannuation funds have in the past—and continue to do so—relied on the provisions of Australian superannuation legislation to argue that they are prevented from paying benefits to the partners of gay and lesbian contributors. Furthermore, the vast majority of funds have followed the advice issued in a circular by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission which states that `spouse' does not include a partner of the same sex.

The Administrative Appeals Tribunal has considered the meaning of the term `spouse' as defined in the superannuation act. In the matter of Brown v. Commissioner for Superannuation, No. V94/638, Justice Jane Mathews found that the partner of a deceased gay man, a contributor to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, was ineligible to receive death benefits under the scheme. The trustees of the fund successfully argued that a same sex spouse was not included in the definition.

Further discrimination occurs through the taxation system, whereby death benefits paid through a superannuation fund to a dependant are exempted from tax under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The definition of `dependency' is similar to that in the superannuation legislation, which means that a same sex partner may be in a position of paying tax on any benefits received from the contributor's estate, when an equivalent heterosexual partner would not.

The most recent edition of Capital Q weekly newspaper highlights the discriminatory impact. I invite members to picture the following scenario. Adam and Sue are co‐workers. Sue has been living in a de facto relationship with John for the past four years. Adam and Steve have been living together in a mutually supportive relationship for the past 15 years. On their way to a work event, Adam and Sue are killed in a car accident.

Adam and Sue have both been members of their respective funds since 1984 and have both accumulated $100,000. Sue died without leaving a will or completing a nominated beneficiary form. On her death, her super scheme identifies John as her spouse. John receives that $100,000.

Adam has been more efficient. He has made a will, naming Steve as his sole nominated beneficiary, and has updated his superannuation beneficiary form naming Steve. The trustees of the fund are able to identify Steve as a beneficiary, but there is no legal scope for the trustees to identify Steve as Adam's spouse. As a result, he is considered a non-dependant and is required to pay $15,000 tax on the $100,000 benefit. John, in contrast, has received the whole amount. If Adam had not made a will and updated his beneficiary form, it is likely that the trustees would not have been able to pay some, or even any, of the money to Steve.

It is plainly unfair that all workers and their partners are not able to receive the same benefits from their equal contributions to superannuation schemes. I daresay, Mr Speaker, that this is not an issue which the Howard government is likely to embrace in the near future. It is disturbing—but probably not surprising—to see in retrospect that, when John Howard claimed during the election campaign that he stood for all of us, he only meant us as in white, middle-class, Anglo‐Saxon, employed members of nuclear families like himself—certainly not gay and lesbian people. The `family values' rhetoric suddenly becomes a bit hollow when we start talking about families headed by gay and lesbian people.

I was pleased to see that the member for Wentworth (Mr Andrew Thomson) was mentioned in last week's Sydney Star Observer as being a supporter of superannuation reform. I wish the member for Wentworth every success in his endeavours to convince his colleagues from the Lyons Forum and other coalition members of the value of giving all Australian workers a fair go, regardless of their sexuality. I look forward to real reform on this issue on the basis of a non‐discriminatory policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, on International Human Rights Day, I want to speak about the contribution that migrants have made to the electorate of Murray and, in particular, to one group, the Albanians. The Albanians came out in the 1920s. In the last century our British and Irish settlers established world‐best dairy, wheat and sheep production. In this century, the Albanians, the Greeks, the Turks, the Italians and the Dutch came out and established our world‐best fruit and vegetable production.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1920s, the Albanians came out literally with nothing more than what they stood in, got to work on the farmland and started to buy and work in orchards. They worked hard, bringing out their families until the 1940s. In 1945, it all stopped. There were no family reunions because of communism back in the home country. The Albanian community in Shepparton continued to thrive, working hard. They built up their mosque. They made sure their children learned both their old and the new ways and they became model Australian citizens. Back home, their homeland, Albania, was mired in economic stagnation. In 1992, communism was replaced by an independent Albania.

The Albanian‐Australian community of Shepparton looked back to their homeland. Although many of them were disappointed to find that our Australian family reunion rules meant that it was too late after 50 years or so of separation for them to recontact their parents and grandparents—that generation had gone—they decided the one thing they could do as Australian‐Albanians was to bring out their distant relatives and friends from their home country and have them learn how to become skilled horticultural workers in the Goulburn Valley.

For 12 months we have had some 20 workers come from Albania to the Goulburn Valley, to train at the Goulburn Valley TAFE and on farms around the district. At the end of the two years, they are going to have certificates in occupational rural studies. The Albanian‐Muslim society fully covers their fee of some $6,000 through their own family sponsorship. They have brought with them their wives and their children. They are absolutely guaranteed to return to their home country, but while they are here they are learning English and becoming skilled.

The Australian‐Albanian community know that this is one way that they can contribute back to their home country and build ties between these countries. They have the country they have now adopted and call home, where they have made such a major contribution as strong, hardworking, honest Australians. At the same time, they recognise that the country of their birth, of their parents and grandparents, needs the skills that only Australia can teach at this time.

I think that is a fantastic example of what multiculturalism is all about in Australia. It is all about our country accepting difference in religion. The Albanian community have their Muslim mosque and we appreciate that mosque in the Shepparton community. We admire their religious convictions and the strength of their teachings as their children from one generation to the next become strong Muslims. We admire their hard work; we admire their contribution to every aspect of Australian society. We also admire their continued association with their home country and the fact that today they are helping to make the new Albania economically independent.

I am proud to speak about the Albanian Goulburn Valley community tonight. I hope these first occupational trainees will go back with a lifelong sense of the friendship that Australia extends. I hope that other ethnic and international groups will come out and also try to learn like these Albanian people have by taking a similar course. Certainly, the Goulburn Valley TAFE will welcome all those oncoming sets of new trainees.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 31 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the migration regulation regarding the independent and business subclasses be amended to allow applicants who have established genuine and continuing same sex relationships to bring their partners with them on the same application as applicants with a spouse or established heterosexual de facto relationship may do.
(2) Is the death of a former nominee a compelling circumstance affecting the sponsor or nominator for the purpose of Regulation 1.20J of the Migration Regulations.
(3) Will applicants who have lodged class 100 and class 110 visa applications earlier in 1996 be queue jumped by applicants for the new class 309 and class 310 visas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government does not consider it necessary or appropriate at this time to alter the definition of `family unit' in the Migration Regulations, which is applicable to all visa classes including business and independent, to include a person in a same‐sex relationship with an applicant for migration. The Migration Regulations define `member of the family unit' as a spouse, dependent child, parent, brother, sister, grandparent, grandchild, aunt, uncle, niece or nephew (and their step-equivalents).

The same-sex partner of an applicant for migration must apply for a visa in their own right if they wish to join their partner in Australia. A person in a same-sex relationship with an Australian citizen, permanent resident or eligible New
Zealand citizen is able to apply for an Interdependency visa for migration to Australia, sponsored by the Australian partner.

(2) Following the disallowance by the Senate of certain parts of Migration Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1996, No 211, the provisions of Regulation 1.20J apply to prospective spouses and onshore spouse and interdependency applicants, but not to offshore spouse and interdependency applicants where disallowance revoked the new temporary subclasses 309 and 310. Following discussions with the Opposition, the Government intends, subject to agreement by the Senate, to reintroduce this provision for offshore spouses and interdependency applicants at an early stage.

The sponsorship limitations specified in Regulation 1.20J are to restrict the number of sponsorships or nominations a person can lodge for a partner (spouse, fiance or interdependency applicant) to a maximum of two in their life time, at least five years apart. Additionally, a person who was themselves granted a permanent visa as a spouse or fiance, or on interdependency grounds, is restricted from sponsoring another partner for at least five years.

These limitations can be waived where the Minister is satisfied that there are compelling circumstances affecting the sponsor or nominator. Compelling circumstances, for the purposes of Regulation 1.20J of the Migration Regulations, are not prescribed in legislation. Each case will be considered on its merits. Policy guidance to assist decision makers is that compelling circumstances could include, but are not limited to, situations where there are children of the new relationship, the new relationship is long-standing, or a previous spouse has died.
(3) Following the disallowance by the Senate of certain parts of Migration Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 199, No 211, the new visa subclasses 309 and 310 have been revoked.
